product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Great Budget Monitor!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on September 9, 2020
text: This review is for the SB220Q series (1920x1080) 75Hz monitor variant.  At a $90 price point as of July 2020, all of the praise this monitor has gotten and continues to get is pretty well deserved.  Right out of the box the factory calibration is pretty awful as with most TVs and monitors (I‚Äôll never understand why that is), but Acer‚Äôs built-in menu gives you a wide range of control to tweak the image quality to your liking.  Here are some of the most noticeable Pros & Cons after using this monitor daily for the past three weeks:PROS:- The colors can be very vibrant and the sharpness makes everything nice and crisp both up close and from a distance without going overboard.  Although the spec sheet does not specify the exact Adobe or sRGB color gamut range, it does have a stated 72% NTSC coverage (keep in mind that the NTSC color gamut has the highest level of color reproduction), which would imply that it should have close to 100% sRGB coverage.  This is pretty standard for most sub $200 monitors (note: the unit that TechSpot tested came in at around 93% of sRGB coverage mostly losing detail in the green range so your unit‚Äôs reproduction may vary).  The 6-bits + FRC (equal to 8-bits) color depth is also an industry standard for entry level monitors and is completely fine for casual use.- This montior‚Äôs ‚Äú100,000,000:1‚Äù Dynamic Contrast Ratio (DCR) (non-standardized measure of contrast for videos) definitely seems to outperform my other slightly more expensive budget IPS monitors (the HP VH240a and ViewSonic VS2412-H)  that only have 20,000,000:1 and 50,000,000:1 contrast ratios respectively.  However, note that it still has an industry standard 1000:1 Static Contrast Ratio (measure for non-moving images) which isn‚Äôt great but is perfectly acceptable for casual viewing since only the highest tiered ($400+) IPS panels exceed that point with 1,500:1 being the maximum native contrast typically achievable with an IPS.~ A quick side note about that ‚Äú100,000,000:1‚Äù DCR number:  there is no industry standard methodology for this particular measurement so the number itself is mostly useless marketing fluff.  But as I noted, compared to the two other monitors with the same industry standard SCR, this monitor did seem to outperform them both in that area.- Its 102 PPI pixel density actually makes a subtle difference in image quality when viewing up close compared to my 24 inch 1080p monitors that have a 92 PPI.  Text seems to be a bit smoother in comparison.  This is purely an advantage of having the smaller 21.5 inch screen.- The Color Adjustment Menu allows you to adjust both the RGB and CMY gains, bias, hues, and saturation levels to get a better color balance.- The Picture Menu lets you adjust the screen‚Äôs brightness, contrast, gamma, and blackness (‚Äúblack boost‚Äù) levels while also providing a ‚Äòblue light‚Äô, ‚Äòadaptive constrast‚Äô (ACM), and a ‚ÄòSuper Sharpness‚Äô on/off switch.- The Game Menu has FreeSync (for AMD GPUs) and Overdrive optionsCONS:- The bezels are a bit thicker than I woud‚Äôve liked (they‚Äôre about 1 cm on the top, left, and right sides) making the frameless design nothing more than a gimmick.- The top-down viewing angle is noticeably darker compared to looking at the screen head on.- Despite having a good DCR of 100M:1, the blacks are still a bit too bright for watching anything with heavy dark scenes since the display itself does not have any HDR capabilities with high contrast control zones aka local dimming (to be fair, this is completely expected at this $90 price point and is only being mentioned as reference for those that may be thinking of using this monitor to watch TV/movies).- The Picture Menu‚Äôs ‚ÄòSuper Sharpness‚Äô option is just an on/off switch; it does not give you a more granular adjustment control over the amount of sharpness to apply.- Even with all of the image quality adjustment options available in the settings, the whites remain on the slightly warmer side of the color temperature chart.  It‚Äôs not that noticeable when viewing on this monitor alone, but the difference can be seen if you have another slightly cooler display adjacent to it.  This is most likely just an issue with my particular unit since other reviews have noted their unit had a more neutral or ‚Äúnear perfect‚Äù white temp.- It only has a paltry 15¬∞ degree back tilt compared to most other budget monitors being able to tilt closer to 30¬∞ degrees (this is super nitpicky as compromises are to be expected at a sub $100 price point).- The Power button is completely indistinguishable from the rest of the menu buttons (both in shape and spacing).Overall, if you‚Äôre looking for a nice quality budget monitor to look at spreadsheets, word documents, and do some internet browsing or even some light casual gaming, then this is a great choice.  If you are a competitive gamer, photographer, professional editor, or a content creator then you‚Äôll obviously need to invest in a higher spec monitor.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Absolutely Amazing Value - Some other features not even listed!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 12, 2018
text: This monitor is definitely a good value. Does it have superb color and contrast? No. Does it boast the best refresh rate on the market? No. But if you're tight on money, this thing looks and preforms great for the money. It has a Matte screen which does a great job at eliminating glare. The chassis it's enclosed within is absolutely stunning. It features a VGA and and HDMI port. The screen automatically detects signals and turns on when a source is turned on. When the selected source turns off it quickly scans and switches to any other sources. If no connections are available it goes into standby automatically. The power chord is a good 6 or more feet and easy to wrap with half of it being very thin wire. The ON LED is not distracting or too bright. When it's off it looks like a borderless monitor. And unlike what other people say it does have tilt, just not forward or left to right. It stands up straight or leans back. Unfortunately it doesn't have VESA mount holes, but under 100 you can't be that serious about your monitor setup. Small text has some problems fully rendering when using VGA so I recommend using HDMI. If you use the Windows 10 settings to configure how text is displayed though it fixes this, but not all will know how to do that. It doesn't have speaker, and I am thankful that most monitors don't. This monitor has A LOT of settings for gaming, night use, color adjustments, and general settings and all can be saved into 3 different gaming profiles. You can even change what settings appear in the quick menu. When u press any of the menu buttons, the menu pops up and clearly illustrates all the buttons. This monitors menus are super easy to understand and navigate and that's a rarity in its own. Also worth noting; it can display crosshairs and display the monitors current refresh rate. It also packs FreeSync for AMD graphics card users. If you only have DVI, you can get DVI to HDMI chords as long as your computer's video out supports it. The base and monitor couple together with one screw that features a hand flap so you don't need a screw diver if you don't want to use one. It is decently sturdy and the screen doesn't distort even when pressed on with strong pressure. The base is quite large, but wont be a problem for most. I haven't noticed any screen delay compared to my 300 dollar 1ms response time monitor (and I'm pretty picky). It's contrast is a little flat in some scenarios but appears much more dynamic in games, especially with some tweaking. With that said, I like that it looks flat when working on documents because it makes it much easier to focus.All in all, this monitor is filled with a good balance of features and looks like a very solid 1080p 75Hz IPS screen for any monitor under $160, let alone the $80 I paid. If you don't absolutely need a better refresh rate and aren't planning on spending more than 200 dollars then I would say just buy this monitor. It's durable, feature packed, and looks fantastic in all use-case scenarios. I'd give it 1000 stars if I could.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Affordable, decent quality, occasional pixilation, very green (RGB)
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on March 28, 2023
text: Bought this after my Asus monitor started to get bad. At first, I had a problem where the image was very yellow, which I noticed when the white Acer logo appeared green. I was not able to fix it on my computer, I had to mess with the monitor's RGB Gains, which was aggravating my hand since the controls were on the underside of the monitor. After a couple of days of trouble shooting, I got the whites to an acceptable tone. Occasionally, in areas covered by a flat bright color, such as an image of the sky, I could see the pixels, but it can be overlooked, especially if you are playing a game or watching an action movie.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Don't forget to buy an HDMI
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on February 8, 2023
text: This is my second of these monitors that I have purchased, so even though I have not used this particular one yet, I will review my previous one.  I am bookkeeper, not a gamer.  This screen has served me so well as a second screen for my iMac, that I am purchasing another one so I can have 3 screens.  Sidenote, I have even packed this screen up and taken it on the road, the screen got scratched (of course) but otherwise, I had no issues dragging it around with me in a laundry basket in my rough riding pickup.Let's get to where this product lost a star.... it doesn't come with an hdmi cable.  It has the old pin style connector in the package.  If it was the only screen I was connecting, this would be fine, but if you're buying this as a second or third screen, order an hdmi cable (or whatever you prefer).  I feel like hdmi mostly replaced the old pin style a long time ago, and it would not have cost acer much to put both cables in the box, hence... 1 star lost.  Overall, a plenty good screen.

title: Very Light-Weight
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2023
text: I bought these monitors to replace the VGA monitors I'd previously been using. I'm pleased with the size, brightness, and picture quality -- all a huge improvement over what I had been using, and at a great price. HOWEVER. These monitors are VERY thin and light, with a lightweight base. The result is that they move VERY easily. If I bump my desk, the monitors shift. If I have to reach behind them (such as to feed a cord behind the desk), I'm afraid I'm going to bump them and tip them over. If I'd shopped for these in store instead of online, I would have purchased something that's more stable/more hefty. Overall, though, I'm happy with them.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Best Budget Monitor
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2023
text: For $90, this is the best monitor you will get. I was on a budget and decided to get this monitor as an external display for my laptop, I use it for gaming and everyday use.Pros:- Good size (I wasn't looking for a big monitor)- Fairly thin bezels. They are still a bit thick but aren't as bad compared to other monitors.- Decent color accuracy- 75Hz is fairly smooth. There is some ghosting when you're gaming, but if you don't pay too much attention, you won't notice.- Good for gaming.Cons:- Took me a while to calibrate. This monitor does not come out color accurate out of the box. The whites aren't always white and blacks aren't always black.- Screen bleeding. Being an IPS display, it's kind of bound to happen. If you lower the brightness, it won't be so bad (depends on where and how bad your screen bleed is)- No HDMI cord- No built-in speakers

title: Great monitor, but experience and consistency could be better.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on December 8, 2022
text: Overall, I like these monitors. I bought 2 in order to complete my dual monitor setup. Being IPS monitors, they have great viewing angles, and the picture quality is very nice. These are considerably better than 2 previously bought items.However, my ordering experience definitely could be better, along with some other things like product consistency. My first order was shipped to a completely different address. Secondly, my 2 monitors seem to have a strange difference. The first one that I received had a max refresh rate of 60hz, despite the label. What's even weirder is that my second monitor DID have 75hz, so either I was given a slightly different product or there's something wrong with it that's not due to the monitor. Finally, I still can't understand why these packages came with VGA cables, rather than HDMI. It really doesn't make sense in my opinion.I'm not too bothered by the refresh rates, as I only need the 75hz as my main monitor while my second monitor can be the 60hz. However, I just wish that consistency could be improved.

location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2019
text: I purchased this monitor for my wife to use with her Alienware R17X4 laptop. She had broken a key on her keyboard but also wanted a little larger screen. So, I purchased a wireless keyboard and this monitor. She now uses the powerful Alienware laptop as a desktop with a larger display and a wireless, movable keyboard. She is a very happy camper.Others have commented on the great graphics, thin design, and good quality build for a great price, so I won't repeat those details here. I will however point out a few tips:1. At first, it seems the stand will not tilt. But it does! Grasp the stand firmly and then tilt the monitor back to the desired position. Note it does not tilt forward or side to side, but does tilt back (facing more upwards towards your eyes) which really helps in most settings.2. If you don't get a signal, make sure you plugs the HDMI cable into the "HDMI out" port on your PC, not the "HDMI in" port. Duh. I had mine plugged into the wrong port until I found my reading glasses and saw the problem.3. We changed three settings which you may want to also do if you have a laptop. First, we changed the display settings to choose between "Second screen only", "Duplicate",  or "Extend". We chose "Extend" so she can have two documents open at once on the two monitors, her laptop screen and the new monitor. You just drag one document off the edge of the monitor to move it to the other screen.4. Next, we found that closing the laptop, when she only needed one screen, put it into hibernation and shut everything down. We went into Control Panel and changed Power Settings under "What happens when you close the lid". We changed it from "Hibernate" to "Do nothing". Now the laptop keeps running even when the laptop is closed.5. Third, most Windows laptops are configured so you have to drag things off the right edge of your new remote monitor to get them onto the laptop screen. However we wanted her laptop setting to the left of her new monitor, so it was confusing to have to drag something off the right-hand edge of the monitor to get it onto the left-hand screen on the laptop. We went back into display settings, where you can drag the two monitors in the settings to reverse them. Now, she can drag items from the left-hand screen to the right-hand screen by dragging them in that direction, and vice versa. Much more intuitive to use that way.With those changes to the settings, she can open the laptop and use it as two monitors, dragging and dropping documents and apps from one screen to another. When she closes the laptop lid, it reverts to a single monitor (the new Acer) but does not go to sleep. This is perfect for what she needs. She can still power off the monitor when not needed for an extended period. Also, the laptop speakers still work when she turns on the sound even when the laptop is closed.I highly recommend this monitor for anyone wanting a very good quality, cost-effective solution.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Used In My Zombie Containment Unit for Halloween
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2019
text: ¬†I bet you didn't expect to see a review with this type of usage of the monitor, did you.  I built a zombie containment unit for Halloween a few years ago in which it used a monitor to give the illusion a zombie was trapped inside the unit.  I used a very cheap monitor in the past and found that it looked okay when looking straight on at it, but any angle from the sides or from the bottom would wash out the image and the illusion was broken.  Given that the "window" was about 5 and a half feet from the ground, anyone shorter couldn't view the video.So, I found that I needed a type of monitor that had wide viewing angles so you can see it from off angles instead of just straight on.  This monitor has an IPS board that allowed for these sharper viewing angles.Here are some things that I looked for when researching a monitor to buy:* Largest monitor I could buy for under $100 USD* Lightweight as it would be hung on the inside of the "unit"* Bright/vivid video* Sharp viewing angles without loss of image quality* at least 22" diagonal width.  The previous monitor was only 15" so I wanted to get a larger size for more realistic size "zombiie" within.This monitor checked off all the boxes.  I also had a $15 Amazon gift card which softened the hit to the wallet.Once received, I hooked up the power cord and an HDMI cable that went to a small digital video player that had a memory card which played the trapped zombie clip.  I didn't attach the base as doing so would not allow me to mount the monitor inside the cabinet.  This isn't a Halloween prop build video so any details of the unit is limited to the monitor itself.I used a felt material inside the cabinet along the edges where the front of the monitor would be in contact with to protect the screen as this is a bezel-less screen on the top and sides.  I didn't want any scratches!  No bezels was the only real drawback to the monitor.  Funny to think that as any other use would welcome no bezels.Anyway, the clip I uploaded is the monitor integrated within the cabinet.  I'm really happy with how it turned out and having this monitor has really took this prop a notch up.Overall, I recommend this monitor if you are looking for a monitor with sharp viewing angles.  Colors are good, no dead pixels on my screen and the price was right for the size.  Other than how I use it, I can't say much more.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Good deal for a throwaway monitor
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2021
text: I used to live in a cool, quiet house in a valley but had to move into a hot and noisy apartment in the city, with no A/C. The temps inside get up to 88 F on a hot day with a 90 F high! As room temp is considered to be 68-72 F, I was worried about my high end Lenovo ThinkVision monitor ($300) and HP color laser printer ($400) being fried or corroded in the heat and humidity of this wretched climate. So I placed both in my air-conditioned self storage unit while I look for better living conditions.To replace them, I decided to buy this $85 Acer monitor and an $85 HP inkjet printer (which costs less than a black toner cartridge for my color laser) and I could pretty much dump then when I move abroad to live (my main intentions). While the Acer is no match for the color saturation, overall screen quality, and bells and whistles of the Lenovo (which was pretty much hand-picked at Best Buy before I pulled the trigger on a good monitor), the Acer has surprised me for such a cheap monitor. It's sharp and color contrast is excellent. My main issue was the screen background being yellowish-green compared to my Lenovo or my Dell XPS, however it got whiter with time as the monitor burned in. In addition, I used the preset screen settings and found a couple that was able to whiten up the screen quite a bit, so that now, it's not bad at all.For $85, I expected soft, blurry text with dull colors in which case I'd return the monitor but I have no complaints now: sharp, excellent color saturation and contrast, and decently white background. Just be aware it has ZERO USB ports, no USB charging port, no HDMI or DisplayPorts, and no audio out port - nor height and tilt adjustments - like my Lenovo. In addition, Acer deleted the audio out port that the earlier models had. Well, I guess you get what you pay for. It's probably worth it to spend 3-4X the cost of the Acer to get a good monitor like the Lenovo, but for my purposes, the Acer suits me fine. I might have to find room in my self storage to keep the monitor as it's too good to throw away!

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Tilt controversy solved
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2019
text: Good monitor for the price.  Nice picture, no dead pixels.  Menu system allows for lots of adjustments, but is hard to navigate thanks to a roughly 5 second timeout if no buttons are pressed.  Be sure to download the .PDF manual, it has lots more information than the printed one that comes with the monitor.Both manuals say that monitor will tilt, but at first it would not budge with any reasonable degree of force.  My husband, whose mechanical skill is high, looked over what appeared to be the hinge joint at the top of the base pedestal.  It's made of steel, and it looked like there was a nut that controlled the friction of the hinge.  However, the nut is inaccessible to a wrench while the hinge is installed in the pedestal.  Removing four screws from the pedestal allowed the hinge to come out.  Loosening the nut did not free up the hinge as expected.  The rivet on the other side of the hinge joint was still causing excessive binding.  Application of some silcone lube didn't help, nor did working the hinge back and forth using tools.  Eventually my husband resorted to drilling off the driven head of the rivet and punching it out.  Note there are several small washers on both the screw and rivet that need to be kept track of.  Rivet was not reusable.  It has a shoulder on it, which should have kept it from binding the hinge, but apparently the wider portion of the rivet was too short.  He replaced the rivet with a 6mm screw.  This involved both reaming the hole in the outer hinge bracket and grinding the screw head so it would fit inside the pedestal.  A nut was installed just a little more than finger tight on the new screw.  Some Loctite might be advisable for monitors that get frequent tilt adjustments.The original screw, stack of washers, and nut was reinstalled, and the nut adjusted to what seemed the correct degree of tightness.  The hinge was reinstalled in the pedestal.  When the base was attached to the monitor, it tilted easily and stayed where it was put.This job took a considerable amount of skill, and probably voids some warranty or other.  Not for the clumsy or faint of heart.  FWIW, many users will likely find that loosening the friction nut will free up the hinge enough to make it work properly, without dealing with the rivet.The hinge is well designed and plenty beefy, and the amount of leverage available to the user when it's joined to the base and monitor is considerable.  However, there's a high risk of breaking the plastic parts of the monitor case or pedestal if the user gets too frisky.  A little more attention to QC by Acer or its suppliers should have made this a non-problem.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Good Monitor
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2019
text: This monitor is definitely a good value. Does it have superb color and contrast? No. Does it boast the best refresh rate on the market? No. But if you're tight on money, this thing looks and preforms great for the money. It has a Matte screen which does a great job at eliminating glare. The chassis it's enclosed within is absolutely stunning. It features a VGA and and HDMI port. The screen automatically detects signals and turns on when a source is turned on. When the selected source turns off it quickly scans and switches to any other sources. If no connections are available it goes into standby automatically. The power chord is a good 6 or more feet and easy to wrap with half of it being very thin wire. The ON LED is not distracting or too bright. When it's off it looks like a borderless monitor. And unlike what other people say it does have tilt, just not forward or left to right. It stands up straight or leans back. Unfortunately it doesn't have VESA mount holes, but under 100 you can't be that serious about your monitor setup. Small text has some problems fully rendering when using VGA so I recommend using HDMI. If you use the Windows 10 settings to configure how text is displayed though it fixes this, but not all will know how to do that. It doesn't have speaker, and I am thankful that most monitors don't. This monitor has A LOT of settings for gaming, night use, color adjustments, and general settings and all can be saved into 3 different gaming profiles. You can even change what settings appear in the quick menu. When u press any of the menu buttons, the menu pops up and clearly illustrates all the buttons. This monitors menus are super easy to understand and navigate and that's a rarity in its own. Also worth noting; it can display crosshairs and display the monitors current refresh rate. It also packs FreeSync for AMD graphics card users. If you only have DVI, you can get DVI to HDMI chords as long as your computer's video out supports it. The base and monitor couple together with one screw that features a hand flap so you don't need a screw diver if you don't want to use one. It is decently sturdy and the screen doesn't distort even when pressed on with strong pressure. The base is quite large, but wont be a problem for most. I haven't noticed any screen delay compared to my 300 dollar 1ms response time monitor (and I'm pretty picky). It's contrast is a little flat in some scenarios but appears much more dynamic in games, especially with some tweaking. With that said, I like that it looks flat when working on documents because it makes it much easier to focus.

title: WHAT I GOT for and WHY I gave FIVE stars
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2021
text: First, NOT a gamer, and to put mildly, NOT into tech...at all. I'm turning 70 and haven't had to deal much with changing out monitors or desktops in some time.  I just turn it on and expect it to work.  I'm saying that so you can tell set up was so easy.My old monitor, that was inches smaller than the 21.5 (I got it over a decade ago) had been used over 11 years and was a floor model when I bought it!  It was great, but could tell it's days were numbered.I stream movies, email, stuff like that.  Just wanted a simple, inexpensive, but decent monitor and my very Tech nephew (he is in charge of tech for a company) recommended this one for what I wanted to pay.PICTURE QUALITY/CLARITY - For what I use for, GREAT.  I can't speak to how it would be for gamers.  Great for streaming movies.PRICE:  It was on sale when I got it so it was a total of about 90 bucks with tax (I have Prime free ship)SET UP - OK the manual I found worthless.  Yes, I can just follow the cables, but this monitor was a tad different than my old one.  My nephew, in three sentences, over the phone, told me exactly what to do and it was super easy.  I DID find it easier to put this monitor in my lap, do the plug ins, put the stand on, and then move to my desk where I connected to my computer rather than try to set it up on my computer table.  This monitor is SO much thinner than my last one.I waited to write this review til I had it at least a couple weeks and, so far, very happy.  If anything changes, I will DEFINITELY edit!BOTTOMLINE:  Would get again.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: if you're a budget gamer like me and don't care for VESA mounting, this monitor is for you
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2021
text: I have purchased this monitor 4 times in the span of 2 years for myself, my sister and my dad. They were around the $90-93 price range. I gotta say, for the price, I am very satisfied with how well it's done for me. My family also has no complaints using this monitor with their own PC's. The bottom base of the monitor is super easy to install. No built-in speakers, but if you use external speakers and a headset like me, you don't even need/want them. As I mentioned in the title, these are not VESA-mountable so if you're looking to mount these monitors, look elsewhere.Some of my main games are League, Apex, Monster Hunter: World, Final Fantasy XIV, Final Fantasy XV, Call of Duty: Black Ops 3, and Tekken 7. This is a decent range of graphics intensive and non-graphics intensive games. I had zero issues with response times and frame rates. They all run smoothly with my GTX 1060 (as long as you play on medium-ish settings). Sure the colors aren't mind-blowing but I don't care at all. I personally think it kicks ass for the price.When it comes to non-gaming stuff, like school or work, there's not really much to ask for other than a monitor that can turn on and work, and this monitor is definitely capable of doing everyday tasks. The 75hz is also very nice.I don't use these monitors anymore as I have upgraded my setup, but I should mention that during the last few months of using these monitors (I had a dual monitor setup), one of the screens randomly goes black every now and then, then turns back on. It can get pretty annoying and can even cost you during crucial moments in-game.Other than that, this monitor was part of my first gaming PC build and I am still very happy for how much it has done for me. A very solid start, whether you're a gamer like me who can't afford an expensive monitor or if you simply need a cheap but good monitor that can get the job done.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Good for the price, but probably better options
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2019
text: First things first: please treat this review as a "3.5 star", which is what I would rate it if Amazon allowed me to.My main issue with this screen is that it has to be the sorriest excuse of an IPS/AHVA/PLS panel I've ever seen. The viewing angles are actually so bad for left/right that there is only a very small position where I can leave my head so that there is no discolouration on the sides, worse than any TN panel I've ever seen. Also, it looks like there is a lot of excess light directly off center to your head's position, as if there is backlight bleed that shifts as you move your head left and right while staring at the screen.Since this was purchased to be my second monitor, it isn't that big of a problem to ME specifically... but it also means it's impossible to keep my head in the perfect position, due to it being off-center to me. I actually had to tilt the screen somewhat sideways (instead of being flush next to my main monitor) so that the sides would mostly look normal in terms of colour.Now I WILL admit that it is possible this is a defect with my actual screen, possibly some problem with backlight bleed or something, but since this is my only sample size, I must rate it accordingly. If Acer has a problem with my statements, they should step up their quality control game and not let a monitor like this pass inspection for sale.Now, the good! For a breakdown, I've rated this a 4/5 for gaming, 3/5 for picture quality, and 5/5 for brightness, here's my take on each:- The input lag is quite low; there is no system lag while working on it. Being above 60Hz also gives it a solid edge for gamers. Gamers generally care less about viewing angle issues like what I described, so as a gaming screen this should not be too bad. Unfortunately I still cannot ignore the viewing angle problem due to how bad it is, and I will never rate any screen below 120Hz as 5 stars for gaming, so it settles at 4.- Picture quality is actually quite good. The contrast is great and the colours very crisp - if the viewing angles and backlight shenanigans were a non-issue i would probably even rate this 5 stars (largely considering the price), but alas, 3 stars.- For brightness, it's certainly bright enough for my needs, though I've not used it in direct sunlight. The anti-glare works well and it keeps its picture quality and visibility perfectly fine even with a flashlight shone at it. I cannot ask for more, so full marks here.All in all, for $90 I cannot truly complain. It does its job of being a screen for discord, watching videos/anime, and handling my stream alerts/notifications. It's light and easy to set up, the on/standby light is not bright yet still well visible, so not distracting in a dark room. Unfortunately viewing angle issue and discolouration it produces ALONE is enough for me to say consider other options, but the rest of the screen pulls it up a bit.If this is going to be your main monitor, and you are not someone who does little but game on your computer? Stay far away. If you need a cheap, decent screen for gaming or this is going to be a low-importance second monitor? I'd say it's up for consideration, if only because it's 75Hz at this price point.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Wish I had gotten this sooner!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2020
text: My laptop screen finally burned out and I needed a quick but still decent solution since a whole new computer is out of budget right now. Boy, did I luck out finding this! At 22" it's about a 5" upgrade from the original screen in roughly the same footprint on my desk. And wow is it SHARP... and BRIGHT! I can now sit back further from my desk without straining my eyes while editing photos, reading, and watching videos. Since I'm not a hardcore gamer I can't speak to its performance in that regard, except to say that emulated DOOM ran perfectly smooth and looked great on it :-DMy only real gripe is that the buttons for power, display settings, etc are located under the bottom edge of the screen, which is really inconvenient, and there's no labeling or anything on the front edge to correspond to which button is which, so until you learn the layout by muscle memory, you might have to do like i did and keep the diagram from the manual as a cheat sheet. Once you get into the menus, however, there are plenty of options to tweak to your heart's content. I really like that there's a "blue light" setting for working at night or when you just want to give your eyes a break (obviously, you wouldn't want this on if you're editing photos, but for reading it's fantastic). There's also a display widget for certain models that you can download from the Acer website that gives you point-and-click desktop access to some of these adjustments without having to use the monitor buttons. A nice touch, but it would be nice if ALL the features could be accessed through the widget as well.Setup is plug-and-play; I literally had this out of the box and ready to go within minutes (you will need to supply your own HDMI cable if you don't have one; only a VGA cable is included). Apparently some models have built-in audio; I can tell you that the SB220Q that I have does NOT have audio out, so you will need external speakers to run the sound from your system out to if that's an issue.VERY happy with this value monitor!

title: Not sure how its ranked #1
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on May 2, 2019
text: The attached picture shows the blurry text that only started happening after switching from my tv to this. I changed no settings other than making text bigger after switching from my tv to this so why are things so grainy and blurry with this "number 1 ranked" monitor?  I only bought this monitor to help my eyes.. I have bad eyesight and as I age it's getting worse. Going from a 43 inch tv to a 21inch monitor is difficult but It's helped me enjoy streaming more since I still use my tv for streaming. It's helped me play LoL better because now I don't have to look two feet to the side anymore lol. I am disappointed with how hard it is to clean the screen. My tv screen is also hard but it never absorbed water(maybe my tv has a coating or something). I wish I would have known this screen absorbs things before I tried to clean it.. Made a permanent smudge(maybe its not permanent and I just don't know what cleaner I'm supposed to use on screens). I had old monitors that were SO easy to clean the screens(LCD flat panels..). Since I've been using this monitor and keeping my tablets blue light filter on I have not had a single eye strain related eye twitch. I just wish it were capable of being cleaned and that things weren't so GRAINY.  The only reason why I'm not sending it back is because it's clearly helping my eyes not get as strained..... I would have given it less stars if I didn't care about my eyesight as much. I can confirm it has tilt but I couldn't figure out how to get the tilt to STAY tilted without re screwing those two screws back in(which made it not tilt anymore lol..) So I wedged a Popsicle stick in it to keep it SECURELY tilted. Luckily I can't see the eyesore when using the monitor even with it tilted back. I'm not sure why it takes 6 seconds for this monitor to turn on. My entire pc only takes 13 and its 8 years old(with a newer nvidia gpu that makes me want to go back to amd sometimes). I wish the power light didn't blink when in standby mode. I'd love to not turn this monitor off when I'm not using it because it goes to standby mode very quickly after my pc is off and only uses 0.05 watts more than being off and plugged into outlet but that blinking power light is too annoying.

title: I am a bit disappointed

text: OK, FIRST of all, I only got this about 2 hours ago, so keep in mind that this IS subject to change.  FIRST pros!1. The ease of use was fine.  After hooking it up, I simply hit the on button, the first switch from your right just to the right of and behind the prominent LED.  The led is subtle and blue when on. The picture is fine.4. If you have a VGA monitor, it comes with a cable for it.  I got a long hdmi cable to hook it up.5. The price seems about PERFECT!  It seems the smaller ones are not much less, if they are at all, and ones that are slightly larger cost a LOT more, so this seems to be the current sweet spot.  And in this range, this particular model is probably about in the center of the price range.The ONE con I had was that I spend so much time looking for a monitor with a good track record, that I slipped up on getting my one nice to have I hoped for, AUDIO.  This has no audio, apparently.  Otherwise, it is FINE for the moment.  I spent a while, and even went to anther company, to make sue the reliability and features were there.  Here's hoping I feel the same way 2 years and more from now.  The last monitor I got, for another system about 4 years ago, and STILL working well, is a model that isn't made any more, and the related monitors have a lower general rating than I would like, so I picked THIS one.BTW I didn't rate gaming, as I don't play games.  I imagine it is about as good as most monitors here.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: FOR OLDER MAC MODELS: Works Seamlessly with late 2015 27inch iMac But You MUST buy an adapter
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2021
text: Wow, I was shocked at how easily and quickly I was able to set up a second monitor for my late 2015 27 inch iMac!Because my iMac is an older model, I had to purchase a Mini DisplayPort (Thunderbolt) to HDMI Cable.This is the one I bought and it worked GREAT: iVanky Mini DisplayPort (Thunderbolt) to HDMI Cable.https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0757JWW81/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1Please note: This cable WILL NOT WORK WITH THUNDERBOLT 3 (USB-C) Macs. This cable is for older models.The product description page for this item will list exactly which mac models are compatible with this cable/adapter.Here's my experience with connecting the Acer monitor to my iMac:1.  I connected the Thunderbolt (aka Mini Display port) to the back of my iMac.2. After placing the monitor on my desk next to my mac, I connected the HDMI end of the iVanky cable to the Acer monitor. I then plugged the monitor into an outlet.3. I turned the Acer monitor on AND IT AUTOMATICALLY displayed as a second monitor WITHOUT me having to go into my macs system preferences to set anything up!It...just WORKED!I'm using this monitor ONLY to display documents, browser windows and other reference materials while I study online so I can't speak to the picture quality or any other technical aspects. I just know it was a breeze to set up as a second monitor to an older iMac. But picture looks fine and colors look great.Just remember to get a Mini Display (Thunderbolt 1 or 2 NOT 3) to HDMI cable like the one I mentioned.FYI this came with a VGA cable only.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Glad I bought this
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2019
text: I got my monitor today and it was easy to set up right out of the box. There is only a vga cable and power cord in the box.I bought this to use with my older mac mini (mid 2011) using a thunderbolt to vga adaptor that I already had. However I tested it right out of the box as a second display with my Acer windows laptop. My review is therefore for these two systems as shown:1) With Windows (Acer) laptop: I connected the vga cable to my acer laptop and it instantly recognized and duplicated the screen without a hitch. There is a bit of tilt to the monitor on the mount which allows it to be adjusted backward or forward (like an up or down neck motion). The colors of my desktop wallpaper appear true to the original and crisp, however words were blurry until I updated the drivers in Windows Device Manager and tweaked the resolution to be the same on both regular setting and 'active signal resolution.' ONE WORRISOME ISSUE came up: There is a horizontal flickering/flashing white line near the top of the monitor running two-thirds across the width. It did not affect the display because it was outside where the display frame would be but it made me think the monitor was internally damaged. UNTIL I connected to my Mac Mini...2) With Mac Mini mid-2011:  Immediately after using the monitor for about two hours as a second Windows display to my Acer laptop, I disconnected from that system and connected the monitor to my Mac Mini 2011 model. Without any need for additional tweaking the display was immediately recognized, resolution and scaling were good, and my wallpaper slideshow is breathtaking. The colors are much more beautiful than the Windows system on the laptop, but I suspect this has more to do with the actual graphics card of the much older Mac Mini. Most notably however, is that the flickering and flashing white horizontal line is not showing on the Mac display. I have no idea what to make of this. Luckily I bought this monitor to use with the Mac Mini so for now I am very happy of the quality and rendering of this display for the price.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Fixed intermittent off/on
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2021
text: I was close to returning this monitor because I was experiencing the intermittent off/on problems that other users have reported.  However, I fixed the problem, and I now am keeping the screen.  I think it's a good product for the money.I am using this monitor with a docking station for my laptop.  I initially used an HDMI-to-VGA converter to then connect a VGA cable to the monitor.  The VGA cable was the one shipped with this monitor.  That setup was very problematic.  The display quality was okay but not great, but the real problem was that the screen intermittently turned off and on, multiple times per hour.  It was unworkable.Today, I went to Walgreens and bought a simple, 6-ft HDMI cable (HDMI plug on both sides, it is not a converter).  I plugged the HDMI cable directly between my docking station and this Acer monitor.  The image quality is now very stable and greatly improved.  I also have not experienced the intermittent off-on issue, even though I have been watching movies with heavy graphics (e.g., I tested it with a trailer for World of Warcraft).So there you have it.  This is a pretty cheap and pretty good product if you use an HDMI cable.  I gave it four stars because it does not work well with the HDMI-to-VGA converter.  Even so, I am happy with the product.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Low Price Low Quality
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2022
text: I bought this TV about three months ago.  I was excited about the price, specs, and AirPlay.  However, I am now seeing why its price was low.  We have found the following issues with this TV:- The picture quality is not as good as expected and the image appears washed out.  We‚Äôve played with the colors and brightness, but that just made the colors weird or the image too dark.- The input naming is not consistent nor intuitive.  It took a few days to decipher what the weird labels meant.  It would have been better to just keep the names HDMI 1, HDMI 2, and HDMI 3.  I would like to have more control on their naming and which ones to display as options.- The audio often does not work when switching to an HDMI-connected device.  We have to disconnect the HDMI cable, or shut off the TV or other device, or a combination of these tricks.  Sometimes it takes a few tries to get it working.- The TV sometimes becomes non responsive, and the power light flashes several times.  We can get it working again after pushing the power button a few times, but it takes a minute.  This usually occurs while trying to get the audio working.- The AirPlay does not work, which is the main reason I went with Vizio and this TV.  It took a few tries to sync my iPhone to the TV, but then it only worked for a few seconds before the TV froze.  This has happens every time I try using AirPlay.This is my first experience with Vizio.  I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs the brand or this specific cheap TV, but I plan to spend a little more to buy a better brand next time.  I would return it and get a refund if it wasn‚Äôt past the free returns period.  The only good thing about this TV is that it keeps you from turning into a couch potato because it takes a lot of manual fiddling to keep it working.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: A Must Buy for Beginner PC Gamers!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2021
text: I bought this monitor for my new PC set up. I spent forever looking for the right monitor and let me tell you I am so glad I made this purchase and saved some money. Lets go with some pros and consPROS:- cheap! Super great price!- Slim! It is sleek and fit perfectly on my small desk- HD! Covers the whole monitor with no negative space! (my old monitor did not do that)CONS:- Some color rendering! You will probably see when you first open google chrome on your computer that some of the same colored items and displays have lines through them. I am no expert but I assume this is because of the low pixels to render. However, when you open up a game or a video, that goes away, so I wouldn't worry too much about it.- Only 3 outputs! There is a VGA output that is slightly outdated and is not used for modern models of PCs. There is also an HDMI cable which is what I'm using to hook it up to my computer. Then there is the plug. The lack of outputs may limit some possibilities but if you're just looking for a monitor that can display your computer than you should be fine.OVERALL:Really good monitor and especially for the price. If you are just getting into PC gaming like me, and especially if you have a budget, then this is the best option.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Looks great, but comes with some quirks
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 28, 2022
text: The monitor looks great, especially for its price. It has some great features, low latency, and incredible customization.That said, it's also the pickiest monitor I've ever seen. If your computer is not already configured for the 1920 x 1080 resolution, the monitor will refuse to display anything, saying something to the effect of "Input Type not Supported."I had to use another screen to configure the resolution on the OS before I could use this monitor. This also causes issues on bios, since bios will default generally to a lower resolution.Ok, so initial config is done, how is it?The display will go blank for about 2 seconds at a time every hour or so randomly. It does not matter what is going on at the time, gaming, youtube, or idling on the desktop.If anyone knows of a way to reconfigure this monitor to allow for more resolutions and prevent the screen blanking, I'll be happy to change my rating, but as it stands, it's been a beautiful but poor experience.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: for $90 it's a great budget IPS display, but...
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on May 11, 2020
text: I think if all you need is a non-adjustable display with HDMI (and no audio pass-through).. this is a good option.I got this for my father, and his requirements were very simple.Personally, I'd pay an extra 10-15$ and get a display with a bit thicker bezel (I know ppl like the whole "bezel-less trend", but bezels can help with stability and support.  I dropped a LG monitor 22" a few feet and because it has a bit stronger/thicker bezel, it survived.  There is no way this would survive a small fall. This isn't necessarily a bad thing because ppl don't usually drop their monitors, but it's something to consider.  Also, because the bezel is so thin, there is no room for VESA.. and this is where I would take a hard pass for this monitor.  VESA is required for myself. Personally, I don't think anyone who wants any type of customization (with their setup) to purchase a monitor w/o VESA mounting.Overall I would recommend this monitor if it's at $90 and you if you do not need VESA mounting.  Also it's important to note that it does not have audio pass-through, which is helpful if you wanna extract the audio from the HDMI and have no other ways of doing it. I use the audio pass-through on my other monitors to connect to my speakers.  This is helpful for things like use with the Nintendo Switch which doesn't have an audio port on the dock.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Great for video surveillance!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on May 26, 2019
text: ¬†[Edit: Please be aware that the photo and video were compressed upon upload.  The picture is very sharp and colors are bright and accurate.  Also be aware that the original photo was taken with my phone, producing miore patterns of red stripes which aren't really there.  Anyway...]My application is for home video surveillance.  I haven't had it long enough to know if there will be screen burn-in but the price is really good so if that happens some day it won't be a big hassle to replace it.I can't speak for gaming as the refresh rate may not be appropriate for that, although I've enjoyed games at this refresh rate so it might be great -- Find out elsewhere as I have no idea.  Personally for gaming I'd use a bigger monitor but this is the right size for my needs.I'm using the VGA input because that's all my surveillance system has for output.  I was worried the VGA input might not produce a good picture but was pleasantly surprised... it's really excellent.  My photo doesn't do it justice.  I've also attached short video where you can see squirrels running along my fence.I like that this monitor is light weight and very thin.  And yes it DOES tilt on the stand, although it doesn't move up or down.  Personally I will mount it to a wall.  (Actually "in" the wall by cutting into the drywall, then adding a picture frame so it looks like part of the home.)  The thin profile, light weight, and thin bezel will help the installation and produce a good-looking result.I also like that the power supply has a small brick, from which a thin low-voltage cord connects to the monitor.Good picture, great price, and a nice physical profile.  I'm happy!

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Can you imagine a cooler paper weight?
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on March 23, 2021
text: When I first set this thing on my papers to keep them from blowing off my writing table as I enjoy the cool breeze of an open window, I thought, "This seems a little too large for the job; its cumbersome even." As I pondered sending it back down the mountain on the next mule train, the fair-headed shepherdess wrapped gently at my door."Mountain man! Oh Mountain man! Will you tell me another one of your stories? The ones you write and people in the valley read?" She asked as if I would say "no" to such a sweet request.In response, I opened the cottage door and brushed my old, gray, wiry hair out of the way so the young lass could see my eyes smiling as I said, "Welcome again child."But as I opened the door a gust of wind nearly knocked me over. The whole house seemed upset by the blow and papers were flying this way and that. Once I gathered myself I looked at the new paperweight and thanked heaven it was larger than most and sturdy too.My guest chattered on about weather and the unknowns of rogue gusts in the Alps while she tidied up for me. I had just poured myself a pint of brew and seated myself to recover from the mishap, when the young lass commented, "Cool paper weight."

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Perfect, especially for the price.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 19, 2020
text: I use these for work and for gaming. After adjusting the color settings from 50 per spectrum to 70, the colors pop, the screens look fantastic, and these monitors seriously beat out any other in this price range. The 22" size makes these fit perfect on my desk as well, as everything is crystal clear and sharp. Games run at 75FPS with rich color, and there are even gaming modes that work great on different games. These also turn on quickly from sleep. I have had these for almost a month and have had no problems. I also own the 24" version of these, and have had that model for 2 years without any issue. Great monitors, great company, don't listen to the negative reviews if you're looking for a basic solution for work/light gaming.Pros:Minimal IPS backlight glowMonitors turn back on quickly from sleepColor saturation, once tweaked, is fantasticBrightness is great for all day work, doesn't cause eye fatigue from being too brightGaming modes, and a low blue light modeGreat menu panelAdjustable up and downCan mount a webcam, as seen in the picture, without covering part of screen.Cons:No bracket for mounting, but not a big deal if you have a desk with a rising stand as I do.Not adjustable sideways to line up with second monitor. Make sure your desk is very level or you find a clamp or something if you are wanting it to be perfect. Otherwise, as in the picture, they work fine.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Pretty cool.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on July 18, 2020
text: First and foremost, the picture I've included with this review is probably not the best it could be. My room is often dark, but the picture quality is pretty good on the monitor itself.Got this monitor for my new PC build, but I decided to use it for a little bit to see if it's satisfactory. Hooked it up to my current PC and it works like a charm. The colors are vibrant and there's no hiccups or delays that I've seen. This monitor does NOT come with an HDMI cable, as I had anticipated, but does come with a VGA connector only. Be sure to keep that in mind when ordering.The only real issue I have is with the brightness. The monitor doesn't dim to my liking (which is, admittedly, just personal taste), but the max brightness works wonderfully if you like your monitors beaming. It does not have any mounting capabilities that I can see, as it doesn't have the VESA hole patterns on the back, or any hole patterns for that matter.Overall, the monitor is nice to use. It's sleek, thin, and light. It works exactly as you'd expect a monitor to, and it works well in that aspect. If asked if I would order another one, the answer would come down to personal taste again. I like mounted monitors, and this one doesn't satisfy that aesthetic. In the future, I will likely order a monitor that is able to be mounted.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Display Is pretty green out the, box but still good for the price.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on May 17, 2021
text: I have been using this for about 2 months as of writing this review. Over all I'm happy with the display. It is serviceable for the price. Other reviews will make it seem like this display is the greatest thing since sliced bread but it really isn't. You are paying for a cheap display and that is what you get. However it is a really good cheap display. If you understand that then its pretty great. The only complaint that I have with it is the green tint mine had out of the box. I was not able to fix it with the built in display settings which made me sad. I was able to make it look miles better using the windows 10 display color calibration. This, however, only makes it look better when running windows 10.Pros:Clear Display (I don't have trouble seeing the picture, Decent viewing angles)Good BrightnessMate ScreenCheapCons:Greenish/yellowish Tint to displayfeels cheap (Doesn't really matter to me since I never touch it)Overall I recommend it, but do some shopping first. You might be able to find a better display on sale for the standard price of this one.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: VALUE AND PERFORMANCE
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on May 28, 2020
text: This is my first Acer product and I was skeptical in purchasing. but my Hannspree finally went kablooey after 10 years.The ONLY major issue I have had so far after 2 months is in no way because of the product itself but me getting used to a smaller monitor screen. My old Hans was a 28" so going to a 21" definitely takes getting used to, even though most of the time I am on my 15" laptop. I don't know why the size bothers me as much as it does.As for the free sync, it works great with my AMD RX580. Yeah it is NOT 4K BUT for the price it is perfect, again especially with the RX580 (which is pretty much not a 4K GPU anyway).The minor issue for me is again, just getting used to the monitor and NOT the monitor. My old one had speakers built in. This meant I had to break out my old speakers, which are outdated so I spend more time on my headphones.In the 2 months I have had it, no manufacturing issues, knock wood.Would I rebuy? YES, so far.Would I recommend to a friend? YESI find that Acer is a good product and have rethought my previous attitude about them.I absolutely love this monitor. The ONLY thing I do hope and time will tell is that the performance remains as strong as my previous one, lasting 10+ years with no issues except at the end.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Good monitors, but a couple of things to keep in mind.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on March 20, 2020
text: Bought this monitor for my work-from-home setup.  Ordered just one a week back to test out - liked it, looks and performs well, does what I need it to do for the price.  Ordered a second one from a separate Amazon batch, and it too is good.  However, when I put them both together for a dual-monitor setup, I do see some differences.1) One has a warmer LCD, one has a cooler LCD.  I know this is common in the LCD world, and might be due to ordering from separate batches, but I just wanted to mention it.  I adjusted the color balance on the warmer LCD (I prefer cooler colors), and got it the colors pretty close, but I can still see a small difference in color between the two if I have a program open that spans both monitors.2) The height of the bases is slightly different between the two.  I have both monitors side-by-side, and are at the same angle, but one of the monitor bases is just a few millimeters taller than the other.  Addressed this by sticking a few thin pieces of cardboard underneath the stand of the shorter monitor.Moral of the story: if you want more than one monitor, I suggest buying them at the same time. You might have a better chance of getting similar-looking monitors.  If you buy them from separate batches, you may end up with monitors with slight differences.

title: Excited to use this

text: I bought this monitor along with an ASUS laptop because I love the idea of a dual display. I will be using it for school and am looking forward to the easiness of tracking web pages.It's compatible with the laptop I bought, but make sure you get an HDMI cable with your purchase of the monitor. I had the assumption it came with the cable already, but it just has the port for it. My ASUS laptop also had the HDMI port so it worked out perfectly.If you have a laptop that is USB-C I recommend getting a USB-C to USB-A/HDMI adapter. The set up is easy and it doesn't take long. It's super light weight and thin. I almost was scared to drop it even a couple inches because I knew it would most likely crack the screen.The display is nice and it doesn't lag when connected to my laptop. I don't plan on using my laptop and monitor for any streaming (I have an iPad), but the monitor is useful when I have to WFH every now and then. Otherwise, I definitely recommend this monitor. product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Stopped Working, "No Input"
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2022
text: I can't understand for the life of me, why this monitor stopped working after a month. My laptop refused to detect this monitor after some Windows updates. (I hate Windows 11 if that helps.) I suspect the issue is related, but with no "driver" information about this product, (therefore, nothing to download or update) it doesn't make sense. Apparently, simply having the right cords, no power issues, and a healthy laptop isn't enough to make this monitor do it's job. Then again, I did only pay $99.While it worked though, it was great. The quality was good, it turned on well after turning on my computer, and general operation was great. No headaches until this. "No input", and my laptop won't detect it!! I even had a rough time trying to access the menu past the Input selection, but I guess it can't be accessed unless the input is detected? Ugh, I don't know. I couldn't find help anywhere, not even on their website. I couldn't even find the product listing with them. Is this discontinued?Just bought a new monitor from somewhere else with a bigger price tag. If that doesn't help me, not much else will. I'll take it as a sign to read books more often.

title: Overall nice monitor. Wish it had sound, though
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2021
text: Impressive picture quality. The menu controls took me a little while to figure out (they are two button underneath the right side of the monitor). Very disappointed that the monitor has no external sound. I had to buy some external speakers. Acer should make that much clearer in the advertising for this product. I would not have bought this monitor if had I known that it had no sound. I was planning to use this monitor with an older Tivo device I have that has 2 TB of movies, shows, sports, etc on it. I could view the video but it had no sounds until I connected the external speakers to the monitor. After that, it was awesome. (I know that a lot of people are using this Acer monitor as a 2nd screen or other use in which this sound issue is not a problem for them.) Overall, this is a very nice monitor. Came well packaged. Very portable. Can be used in a lot of different settings (home, travel, etc.). Impressive picture quality for a monitor at this price point.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Pleased so far. It does tilt.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2021
text: This is day two of using the monitor. Overall, I'm pleased with the purchase. I did not like the default screen color. It seemed dull. I noticed that the "cool" setting is easier on my eyes and best matches my Macbook Air's screen display. I agree with comments that say the image is not as crisp on the monitor. It's more or less imperceptible unless you're working alongside another monitor that has high image resolution (i.e. my Macbook). I work with scans of 16th century documents, and the monitor display is good enough to work with. I'm not sure what a gamer would say about the resolution. I, too, thought the monitor did not tilt, but it does! Grab the column at the base and slightly push the monitor screen back by pushing at the top of the monitor. DON'T PUSH TOO HARD! It only tilts back slightly, but it tilts back as much as I would normally want to tilt my monitor. Someone else posted a picture that shows you how far back it tilts.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Great Quality!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on July 12, 2020
text: Oh my goodness! I have been using this monitor for around a couple months I would have to say. I have been loving this monitor. Great everything to be honest. Now, sadly if I wanted a second one I might have to upgrade the desk. I personally use mine for console gaming though, so I am not sure how it would operate with a PC.No controller of any sort included, however the monitor does have buttons on the bottom right. The very first one on the right is the power button (when I first got it, this was hard for me to figure out.) and the other buttons switch around a few things. Now for me it automatically detects my HDMI which is great and it also can have VGA cords connected (in fact it comes with a VGA cord).My only dissapointment is that it has no speakers (no audio) so you have to use a headset connected to either your console or PC whichever one you are using it for. If your using a Xbox One be careful, because that console is known for having headset audio issues. Works great with my PS4 though and it did with my Xbox One X as well.Disclaimer: My phone isn't the best with picture quality, so don't judge the monitors quality off of my picture haha.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Important which connection you use
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 27, 2018
text: I purchased this monitor to replace a several years old, but nice Dell model.  The build on this one feels light and cheap, but then it was 1/4th the cost of the previous monitor, and a monitor does not really have to put up with a lot of stress.  I use it for work (browsing, reading, some graphics) and a little personal (video), but not gaming or anything intensive so cannot speak to that.  What I did learn is that the input for video matters, a lot.  Initially I connected the monitor using my current VGA cable (one reason I chose this particular monitor).  The picture was fine, but I discovered that it did a poor job with any photo/video with dark tones.  In a darker or shadowy picture, all detail was lost (the image looks almost black in some cases).  This could not be remedied by adjusting contrast, etc.  It was bad enough that I decided to shop around until I found an alternative monitor, at about double the cost.  Just before initiating the return, on a whim, I changed the input to HDMI.  I figured this was more about HD video quality, etc.  But as soon as I made the switch, everything got better.  Suddenly photos looked perfect, problem solved.  This monitor does not come with an HDMI cable, so if you don't have one, I recommend purchasing one in addition.  The only other thing that is worth knowing is that, as mentioned in the description, this monitor cannot be tilted.  Because the base is round, propping it up is unstable.  For me, its fine, I have it tilted up, and it sits on the desk.  It would wobble at a bump, but its not really ever getting bumped.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Great Starter Monitor
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on April 22, 2020
text: Acer killed it with this monitor. For a gamer, it has a clear Full 1080p display, that also has 75 Hz refresh rate which is perfect to enjoy most games, especially if you are just getting into the PC gaming scene.. I have bought two so far and have not had any complaints on picture quality. I do have a couple of little issues that are just a personal preference more than anything:1) As you might have read already, there is NO Vesa mounting points on this monitor. Now this is fine for the two monitors i bought since the desks i bought them for do not have arms, but I like these monitors so much (especially the price) I wanted to buy some for the office, the only thing is that all of the work stations have computer arms.2) I do wish that this display was a little bit brighter. For the most part it is fine, definitely brighter than other monitors at this price point, but just as a personal preference i wish it could go a little brighter.All in all i love the two monitors that i have bought, and other than the two nit picky things i said above i dont have much else to complain about. For $90 i have not  found anything else that can compete in build quality or picture quality like this monitor.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Great Office Monitors
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on September 23, 2020
text: I use two of these in my home office, the image is crisp and sharp, and plenty bright even sitting right next to a big window. The only criticism I have is they are not "Zero Frame" as the title description indicates. The plastic bezel itself is almost nonexistent with the screen surface going right out to the edge, but the image stops about half an inch (say 5-6mm) from three edges with the bottom a bit wider. If you put them side by side, you will notice it, but it hasn't bothered me at all. Again, not a problem for my use, and I did not deduct any stars.Having said all that? I love these things. The monitors have performed flawlessly since I installed them (I use two) and they match color and brightness perfectly right out of the box. Like I said above, they're sharp, crisp, and bright. I use a (Amazon Basics brand) DisplayPort to HDMI adaptor cable with them and have no issues at all. The power supply is external, but is small and has plenty of cord both on the AC side and the DC side so you can stash the small brick wherever is convenient. I have them next to the monitors.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Good value for the money - for those with blue light issues - may want to think about this
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2021
text: Note: this is a one-day out of the box review - early days yet.  Soooo I'd like to give this 3.75 stars but gave it 4 and here's why - the software control panel night mode shift from my laptop doesn't seem to translate to these monitors when going through my hub.  Honestly, I'm not sure if this is a hub issue (I suspect it is), but I've had other hubs that have the monitors adapt to night mode fine.  Soooo considering if I should return and get a Dell hub/docking station and Dell monitors and go with "what I know" from my workplace, or use the funky controls on the monitor hardware to manually go into "blue light" mode, and adjust down the screen to self-filter in its own hardware to 50-70% blue light.  It is supposed to be known for blue light filtering tech, but that seems a little low techy to me.  Also a little puce colored tone results.  I'll give it some more time and make a decision soon.

title: Good but wish it had more hookups
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2021
text: This Acer has good quality at a low price but be forewarned. I bought this monitor to use as a second monitor for the junky one they gave us at work - so you could have one document open on one screen and a different document open on the second screen. Makes life a lot easier. The problem is the Acer only has 3 hookups in the back: Power connection, VGA (blue pin connectors) and HDMI connector. My old work stuff will not support HDMI and has one DCI hookup and one VGA hookup and Some USB hookups. I've been having a difficult time trying to get around trying to getting both to run on VGA since I only have the single VGA hookup on my laptop docking station. Trying all the cable adapter configs. Bottom line is the monitor is great but if you are trying to run 2 of them off of some old gear, you might run into problems with what can I hook into what since they don't give you a lot of options.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Quality Control Is A Little Bit Concerning
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2019
text: Just bought two of these Acer SB22Q monitors. The first one works completely fine. Switched over to the second one to test it. After 25 minutes of use, a line of dead pixels appeared across the middle of the screen and the bottom half started stuttering. After rebooting, the bottom half still stutters and a line of dead pixels still remains that runs across the middle of the screen. I guess I just got unlucky with getting a faulty monitor, but it is still a pretty big inconvenience having to deal with getting it replaced (hopefully).However, a functional one works great and the picture quality is pretty decent (nothing spectacular). I don't think the iPS makes that much of a difference because it's only 21.5" so you'd be sitting pretty close, but it's still nice to have. Coming from a 13" Macbook Pro, the screen size feels much larger without being overwhelming. If you're looking to have a dual monitor setup, at $89.99 each, it is great bang for your buck. If you want a dual set-up with a VESA stand, you'd have to buy two separate Acer VESA adapters, which would cost you $50-60 for two adapters alone. If you're on a tight budget, definitely consider this monitor. Last piece of advice, make sure whatever monitor you buy (new or used) is covered by warranty because anything can happen.

title: Best monitor for the value!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2019
text: I have been using this monitor every day for about 8 months now so I feel I can write an honest review. I work from home and have it connected to my laptop as my main monitor, the laptop screen being my secondary. First things first: so easy to set up. I bought a 3' HDMI cord and it was 1.2.3... and I was all ready to work. I am a landscape architect so I do a lot of graphics and CAD work and this is perfect for that. I do the drawings/work on this monitor and keep my toolbars open on the laptop screen. It is easy to pack up and move, this was important to me as I am a nomad and frequently am setting up my "office" in new locations. I love the tilt feature, I can adjust the screen for if I am sitting or standing, granted it's not just a "push to tilt" feature, you actually have to loosen the mechanism underneath and readjust. I find the color, brightness, and resolution to be more than adequate for the work I am doing, especially for the price! Maybe if you are gaming or watching movies this might not be good enough (??? I don't actually know because I do neither of those things on this monitor) but for quite literally everything else, it is wonderful. I am considering purchasing a second and using my desktop more than my laptop with a dual set up. Highly recommend.
