product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Bright, user friendly, and affordable
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2020
text: When this monitor first arrived, the packaging was pristine and the monitor fit snugly in the packaging. The setup was extremely easy. The base and the neck of the base come detached from the screen, and they just slide together very easy with no tools required. When you turn it on, it autoscans to find what inputs you have plugged in. This feature can be turned off in the menu. The menu is simple to learn and easy to navigate. You can set the brightness, contrast, etc. manually, but there are also a number of preset profiles you can choose from. The screen can be made to be very bright if you like it that way, but if you're more comfortable with a more dim setting, it's easy to adjust. The color is very good too. The picture of the screen doesn't quite do the real-life experience justice, but the colors are captured very well. I have absolutely no complaints about this screen and will be buying 2 more next month. At $90, which is the price I bought this at, I really have no reason not to buy more. None of my friends believe me when I tell them the price of this screen, particularly after they've seen me gaming on it.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Decent monitor for the price, but got one with a line of dead pixels
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2019
text: Picture quality isn't the greatest, it's an IPS panel, which is nice, but colors look pretty dull. For gaming, motion appeared surprisingly smooth. IPS panels usually have pretty high response times, which leads to ghosting and just motion in general in games doesn't look great, but didn't notice any ghosting or anything like that on this. Also surprised me the options in the menu. Menu is really easy to use and has a blue filter option, gaming options to optimize picture, freesync, has an overdrive option, and the crosshair aim thing.For a really cheap gaming monitor this would work pretty well, but I warn the picture is pretty lacking. If you're just looking for a monitor for web browsing and what not, I'd probably look for something with a little better picture quality.All in all though, probably one of the cheapest monitors I've ever seen and really doesn't disappoint. Main problem I had, and the reason I'm giving it 4 stars, is it has a like 2 inch line of dead pixels. Not sure if they would return it for that, and not sure if I want to deal with the hassle.Oh, and it's super thin, which is nice. It also has the thin bezels, but there's a like half inch black space between the actual displayed picture and the bezels.

title: For the price its hard to beat
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 12, 2020
text: I really wanted to dislike this monitor enough to warrant purchasing something 'bigger and better'. However, I cannot find a reason. My monitor arrived with zero dead pixels and a great picture given the price range.Since building my PC I have been on a 55" 4K TV and later a 32" 720p TV. The additional bandwidth this monitor is capable of makes a noticeable difference in gaming responsiveness.  While I still experience occasional tearing in games where my Video card is rendering frame-rates beyond the capabilities of the 75Hz it's still not enough to warrant going to 144Hz or 1440p. Having a Radeon 580 means most of my gaming still falls well within the specs of this monitor.Although monitor speakers almost always stink. It would have been nice to have a built in speaker and not give up additional desktop real-estate for speakers. Pros:* Good picture* IPS screen* response time* 75Hz* aiming reticle* monitor tilt* compactCons:* Controls are a pain to navigate* No Vesa* No Speakers* Only 2 ports (VGA and HDMI)

text: The monitor is very good for the price, that is my first impression of the product. 4 stars currently since I just bought it and want to see how durable it is in the long run. Colors, Resolution are all on point, I don't game, so I can't speak to how well it performs for gaming. But I do programming, so in that respect it is decent enough.I currently use a mac with this, I use my Mac in clamshell mode since my mac screen broke and it is too expensive to get it replaced. The Mac is connected to the monitor via HDMI, and some customers might experience a downside upon first hooking up the monitor with the Mac: black borders on the screen. This appears to be problem with underscanning, and since Mac removed the underscan adjustment tool, the method I used to get the full screen can be found by searching: "BLACK BORDERS ON YOUR EXTERNAL DISPLAY? HERE‚ÄôS THE FIX FOR MACOS" on google. It is relatively simple, you have to have administrator access, edit a single file and restart computer.Overall, the monitor functions nicely, and it is true you can't beat this price!

title: Really good value
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2019
text: For the money this is really good value. It‚Äôs a great entry monitor for all use cases, office, gaming, entertainment, etc.Comparing it to my 4K monitor that still currently cost 3x as much & a MacBook Pro with Retina display...The 75hz refresh is noticeable for FPS games, it‚Äôs just smoother over 60hz.The picture quality is very good (especially for the price) but I would not call it retina quality like another reviewer. However the quality is good and would be fantastic for most people.The color accuracy is pretty good too but it isn‚Äôt 100% accurate. Greens are a bit saturated and yellow is slightly duller in comparison for me.The brightness is good / average.The monitor I got looked pretty good in build quality. No dead pixels, only very very minor bleeding on one corner. ( only noticeable if testing for it )Overall it‚Äôs a great starter monitor. But, it falls short as a secondary monitor because of the lack of adjustments you can make with the stand and lack of vesa mount. So really this monitor is only good for budget & will have it sit landscaped in a stand on presumably a desk.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Excellent Picture for the Price Point
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2020
text: I purchased this monitor to replace an old HP LCD unit I bought from Wal Mart years ago. I recently upgraded my Lenovo tower with a GTX1650 GPU and wanted something that would A) display the output from the card with quality, B) get away from using a VGA cable, and C) take up less space on my desk. This monitor accomplishes all three of these very well, and my only gripe with it, is that it has no height adjustment. I had to use a box to put under the monitor so that I could see it without looking down. I knocked off a star for this, but if I could've only knocked a half-star I would've. This is truly a very nice monitor with great picture and deep colors, I love how thin it is. I connected it with an HDMI cable to the GPU and it was truly a plug-and-play experience. I would absolutely recommend this to anyone looking for a small LED monitor at budget pricing.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Best Monitor For under 200$
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2019
text: So, i am a gamer(with over 2000 hourse in cs go), i had my previous monitor for 7-8 years and it started flickering and stuff. So i started doing my research, of course at this price point i was not even expecting to get 75hz monitor, i saw this one, i thought ok, its 75hz but its going to have some other drawbacks, i read reviews, i sawYoutube videos and one of the most trustworthy Youtubers actually recommended this one for gaming when on budget. even though i could have afforded something more expensive than this, i was so curious to check this one out, so  i bought this monitor and i had it for couple of days, difference between this monitor and normal 60hz monitors is SIGNIFICANT! I mean playing counter strike is just much more smoother and nicer. also it is really thin and has IPS panel, which is superior to TN panels, because of more accurate colors and viewing angles.So i realized that it is not only best monitor 100$ but its actually best under 150-200$I mean there are some TN monitors which cost 150-200$ and have 144HZ but you are going to be sacrificing IPS panel colours.Also keep in mind that going from 60hz to 75hz difference is bigger than going from 75hz to 144hz.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Wow! WOWOWOW
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2019
text: For the price, I am very happy with this screen!The Color saturation is GORGEOUS and I mean that: It's rich, deep, the blacks are clear and the quality is perfect.  I have larger screens with higher refresh rates that pale in comparison (Literally: their colors look washed out comparatively)I originally only ordered this screen because the thing fit under my roll top desk perfectly, so the 21.5" size was just right there.  But this is a joy to look at.The OSD controls are fantastic because despite them being unlabeled, once you press them the screen shows the controls directly over each button, very well done Acer, very well done.  I can change the brightness in the dark (Which is when I would need to change it) thanks to this.For gaming this did well in Overwatch (It's being driven by a GTX 770M however) - no tearing or anything, the decent refresh rate (75mhz) on this panel, decent gaming performance for the price for mid-range graphics cards (1060/2060 or below).For browsing and writing the screen is perfect to look at, Windows 10 handles the text in a nice crisp manner, the pixels do not show, and it's an excellent image all around.This is an excellent buy for the price: I  would buy another if I needed one this size.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Great but mounting issues
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on July 18, 2019
text: Originally purchased 2. The screen quality and form factor is superb. These things are paper thin, light and have very tiny bezels. One huge problem. They are not VESA compatibile (without an adapter). If you're looking to use these monitors on a separate mount, you might as well look elsewhere. Unfortunately, you are stuck using these with the stand they come with--which all things considered is a decent stand.You can make these monitors VESA mounting compatible, but it requires a proprietary adapter that runs you $20-$30!!! As much as I would like to go the route of adapters, the big issue for me lies in my monitor configuration. I use a monitor in normal, horizontal layout and I use another in vertical layout (useful for spreadsheets.) The "clip-on" mechanism these monitors use to connect to the stand is not ideal--nor would I feel it smart to use--for a vertical monitor configuration. All it takes is one small bump sideways and the monitor would become freed from the mount.  Unfortunately, I am not wealthy enough to take that risk. I need my monitor secured.In conclusion: great monitors, but if you're looking to mount them to anything other than the provided stand, consider other options

title: For the price, it looks ok, buuuut...
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on December 27, 2022
text: It's not horrible for a sub $90 monitor, but--if your computer does support 1920x1080, you get nothing.  Nada. Oh wait, it'll display the text "Input not supported."So what?  Almost every modern graphics card can do 1920, right?Well, that resolution is fine in Windows, but anything before you get into the OS is "Input not supported."This includes the BIOS setup.  I had to use another monitor to configure my son's new computer.  Same power and HDMI cable, but different monitor.I bought two of these monitors, and they both refused to show the BIOS screen.  And, one of them had only half of the screen backlit.Sending them both back for refund.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Great monitor for the price
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 9, 2019
text: Compared to my previous monitor, there's much more contrast on the colors, so they really pop out at you.  Everything looks sharper and prettier.  Also, this monitor has an anti-glare screen, so your view won't be obstructed by background light.  The extra 15hz that this has over my old monitor hasn't stuck out to me yet, but it's nice to have.  It also supports Freesync.  I don't know who still uses VGA in 2019, but it comes with a VGA cord.I do find it strange that it only supports HDMI and VGA, when there are other formats out there, much better than the latter.  It'd be nice to have more than one HDMI port, in case I wanna hook up other devices, but it wasn't a deal-breaker for me.Overall, it's a great monitor for the asking price.  It looks good, displays well, is light and doesn't take up much space.  If you're okay with the limited amount of ports (which seems to be pretty standard for monitors around this price), then you'll be satisfied with this one.  It doesn't have the "Amazon's choice" tag for no reason.

text: Really great price, super easy setup. Note that you cannot daisy chain with the HDMI cable, I have a hub so I can have multiple monitors. So if you have a KVM, or both VGA and HDMI port on your laptop, then buy 2 for dual extended setup. No driver install necessary, they worked right out of the box for me. Really nice quality for such a low price. Note - I do NOT game, so I have no idea how these would work for gamers.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Best solution for a home-office/WFH set up
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2020
text: I bought two of these monitors for the new home office, since working from home is now in style. For $90 a piece, this is probably the best bargain monitor I've ever purchased. The 1080p panel makes those work emails look just as smooth as they do at the real office. I ended up buying a couple HDMI to DisplayPort adapter because my docking station didn't support HDMI, but these monitors still displayed what they needed to display without a problem, even through the displayport adapter.Pros:InexpensiveGenuine 1080pLightweight and thinPower brick has a long cordPerfect for generic office or school work (emails, spreadsheets, documents, random coding etc.)Includes a VGA cable in the event you didn't already have 20 of themColor reproduction is good enough for most tasks.Cons:Did notice some light bleeding along the edges of both monitors, nothing serious though, but it's there.These monitors do live up to the "ultra-thin" name, but zero frame is a stretch. The bezels definitely look bigger in person than they do in those promotion pictures.

title: Great for 2 years
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2022
text: The monitor worked great since I purchased it in November of 2019. The screen is vibrant and 75hz refresh rate has a suprisingly notable improvement over 60hz when gaming. the screen size makes 1080P gaming very crisp. I had no few issues up until one day my computer woke from sleep and had a single verticle line from top to bottom of my display. I wiggled and jostled, pulled the back panel off and reseated the ribbon cable but nothing has changed. The color will occasionally change from red to blue or green, but a big red very near the center of the screen makes it a bit difficult to focus on anything. For the price I purchased it, I shouldn't be upset that it only lasted 2 years, but I am still a little disappointed.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Great basic monitor...
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2021
text: I've been using this with my new Mac Mini M1, and it's been working perfectly for that.  No dead pixels and the picture is crisp, bright and colorful.  It also works with another, cheaper Windows 10 based mini stick PC.  Sometimes I temporarily switch to that to print something, as my mono laser printer is too old to work with my Mac.Keep in mind that the HDMI connection is straight out of the back, so you may want to consider an HDMI cable with one end having a 90 degree connector.  Make sure to look at the pics of the monitor so you get a cable with the 90 degree connector the right way rather than upside down.  This way the cable hangs down instead of sticking straight out.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Defective and Non-Existent Support-_Edit---> Replacement works
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2020
text: Original Review below this edit: Replacement ordered from amazon after returning. Monitor works as intended, but the hassle in getting a replacement with the endless "customer service" loop from Acer will prevent me from ordering another Acer product again.Price paid with tax : $95Arrived on time, but monitor was defective. No damage to box. Tested with two desktop computers (one Nvida GPU, one AMD GPU), a laptop, and an Xbox one. Tested with HDMI first, and VGA second, on all devices except VGA on Xbox. With all devices, same issue exists. Monitor cycles between pink, yellow, and clear hued screens, with a 1 second interval between hues. Tried with default settings first, and modified all settings to try to find a culprit. Nothing stopped the cycling from occurring. I attempted to reach out to Acer on two separate days, via web chat, and phone. After a wait of over 20 minutes for both methods, both times, the web chat said there "There is no one to assist you at this time", and the phone call just dropped. I have just initiated a return through Amazon, instead of trying to deal with Acer. I am a little surprised, as I own 4 other Acer monitors, and none of them have had an issue. I understand factory mistakes happen, or perhaps it was damaged in transit or storage, and that's why I tried to deal with Acer about it. But with over 80 minutes across two days being spent just trying to talk to someone form the company,to ultimately never talk to someone,  I will not be purchasing Acer products for awhile.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi

Picture quality out of the box was great but colors seemed a bit.. dark, I calibrated it enough to be bearable but it's still a bit darker than my 1st monitor. It doesn't bother me too much as I use this monitor for my xbox. I definitely wouldn't use this for artwork though as it seems darker/warmer than my current monitor by a landslide. (Unless, I am just terrible at calibrating)This monitor doesn't appear to have speakers either, which I don't really mind as I'm using headphones 90% of the timeOverall a solid budget monitor for gaming, however I may upgrade it to a second asus monitor so I can have 2 monitors with the same colors as I'm also a graphic designer student :)

title: Amazing value / picture quality
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2018
text: I bought two of these monitors and I am extremely impressed. 1080P + IPS + 75Hz + FreeSync + Thin + Narrow bezels at this price is awesome.1080P at 21.5" has a nice pixel density. Text is very crisp and sharp. Picture Quality wasn't bad out of the box but after some tweaking its looking great!75Hz refresh rate is still a NOTICEABLE improvement over 60Hz. This also costs far less than say a 144Hz monitor. Really a great gaming monitor if you are on a budget. I've only played some Quake Live on it thus far but I really don't notice any input lag or ghosting.FreeSync support - I am not using an AMD graphics card so I can't comment -- but its nice to have and ultimately is why this has a 75Hz refresh rate so no complaints :-)The monitor is impressively thin and having VGA and HDMI is great. No DisplayPort, but I wouldn't expect that on a monitor at this price point.I knocked off a star because I REALLY wish these had VESA mounting. I'm using two of these in a dual monitor setup and having VESA would be great to not only elevate them but also the monitors don't exactly line-up because you get a little bit of variation in tilt with the cheap plastic stands.

title: Best deal! Great screen with a little tweaking.

text: 22inch screen for 90 bucks... you can go wrong.Pros:The damn priceLightweight75HzBrandnameFreesyncCons:No speakersVery flimsy from half way up the screen(as its soo thin and lightweight)Not much tiltLight bleedI read the reviews... was a little hesitant  after reading some of them. But for the price... you wont find a better deal. And turn off the damn 'super sharpness' setting and it will make everything look better! Jeeze!I plugged my screen in and straight away my computer recognized the freesync display, auto configured with 75Hz @1080. It looked fuzzy, as I stated before, so I TURNED OFF SUPER SHARPNESS and that was that! You will have a bit of light bleed from the sides in a dark setting so adjust the screen settings to suit your needs to get the best picture you can.I game fairly regularly and can say the freesync and 75hz makes a difference from gaming on TVs.

text: I bought this item with a new desktop computer. To be honest, I expected the screen to be bigger than what it actually looked like when it arrived. But I do not want to blame that on anyone because the actual size (21.5 inches I guess) was written with the product and it was my reponsibily to check that. One of the things that I liked about this screen is that it is thin which I usually have not seen with other screens. But one of the things that I didn't like was that it was fixed in every direction, meaning that to rotate or anything like that the whole thing had to be moved. And the other thing is that when I was adjusting the screen using my keyboard from the Windows 10 computer, the screen would just pop up and show me the brightness scale going up and down, but it actually wouldn't change the brightness. So, I was a little confused, but then I figured out that to adjust the screen, there are actually buttons at the bottom part of the screen which I can use to adjust the brightness. But I do not know why the command from the CPU didn't work.My CPU which I bought with this product by itself had a problem. So, when I returned that, I decided to return this. This item didn't have any problem. But I thought I can find a better one.

title: Feels cheap but works fine. Issues on older BIOS.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 6, 2019
text: I bought this monitor because it's cheap and supports freesync. Works fine for that.I installed this at the same time I installed a new hard drive, and I had to have a backup monitor for my computer because my bios wouldn't display anything on this monitor. I'd just get an "input not supported" message. Once I installed Windows & appropriate GPU drivers, it started working fine.Basically - this means I have to keep an old monitor in storage in the off chance I have to tinker in my BIOS again. But other than that, it works fine.*update*I had to go through extraordinary measures to get a new video card working which involved using unofficial tools to flash a new BIOS, but doing so seemed to have resolved the unviewable BIOS issues. It's a nice monitor, just wish it didn't feel cheap. If you have an old PC, be aware that you might need to keep an old monitor on hand for BIOS stuff.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Surprisingly Great for Macs
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 1, 2020
text: Bought this as an external monitor to connect to my Macbook Air while working from home during the pandemic. I typically don't like working from home because I preferring working at a desktop (depending on the type of work I am doing). Buying this monitor has been the perfect solution. I've had it for about 3 months now and haven't had any issues. You just need the Mac specific HDMI cord and set up the appropriate display specifications (I think the display wizard popped up automatically the first time I connected the monitor to my laptop but can't quite remember - if not just go to the display settings on your Mac). The display/color quality on this screen is also great, even better than my Mac. I had low expectations for this product since it was so cheap and I wasn't confident about the compatibility with an Apple product, but I'd definitely recommend it for Apple users.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Best Value I Could Find
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on February 1, 2019
text: I did not start off with this monitor. Originally I got another one for Christmas that was about $15 cheaper on Black Friday. I was looking for something to plug my laptop into while at home. Problem was that the old monitor did not have an HDMI port like I thought it would so I returned it. That's when I began shopping around online and found this Acer unit. Sure it was $15 more but it had an HDMI port, which in my opinion should be on everyone's list when buying a new monitor now a days.  Sure, you could go with one that just has a SVGA port for a couple bucks less. Maybe your computer has a SVGA port, you have an adapter, or you planning on investing in a docking station. I still think you would be better off having the HDMI port. You will never be able to get the kind of picture out of SVGA that you get with HDMI and in a couple years Goodwill will be about the only place you can unload monitors with SVGA only. This is a surprisingly versatile monitor for the price. I have had no issues and it has been 2 months now. I highly recommend it.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: You Get What You Pay For
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on January 11, 2021
text: I purchased this along with my first pc build. I was on a tight budget, and with the quantity and quality of reviews this thing had, I figured it was a worthwhile purchase. Once the tower was built, I plugged in my computer (HDMI from the graphics card interface), and was greeted with the message "input not supported". After some research, I learned that I needed to update my display drivers to output HDMI, but, in order to do that, I'd need to get the machine running and install windows, and to do that I'd need to use a monitor. I could have used the Mini DP output on my graphics card, but I learned that the monitor didn't have a Mini DP input. Several hours later, with the help of another borrowed monitor, I was finally able to update the drivers and use this one. All that toil and trouble to see an adequate picture, at max brightness.In short, if you need a Mini DP port, don't use this monitor. For everyone else, this is a good choice for starter monitors, but don't hope to get a great deal. You get what you pay for, and so you might want to hold off on purchasing this, or using it as a second monitor.

text: Great for the price. Only downside was that ours didn't tilt. But after reading a question someone said to loosen the hex bolt inside the stand. To do that we had to dis-assemble the entire stand (pictures shown of the screws we had to unscrew go reach the tilting mechanism.) Once we got to the spot we could not get the nut loose. We ended up holding the nut with pliers and using a hammer to make it tilt. That worked! Once it was all put back together it tilts fine. The nut was way too tight before hand that didn't allow it to tilt. But all is good now and we don't have to dis-assemble it to tilt it back! It's a great montior for the price wish it had speakers but we got some cheaper amazon ones that work great!

text: I have had this monitor for about a month now and I have not run into a single issue. For gaming it works very well and I haven't run into any visual issues or glitches, I'm giving it 4 stars for gaming since it's only 75hz but it's a $100 monitor so what can you expect? The monitor is extremely flat and it's bezels aren't  annoyingly large so it looks just as good as the screen does. The brightness is my only issue since I have it turned down to 0 but I still think it's kind of bright (this might not matter to you but I really like really low brightness). Overall this is a great monitor and it is very worth it for the money, if you're on a budget and don't mind having 1080p over 4k, this is the monitor for you.

I'm not a gamer so I have no opinion on that but if you're just looking for a monitor to just simply get work done then this is the best deal by far. On June 2021, for some reason the menus on the monitor just keep popping up on the bottom right of the screen and just scrolls non-stop.  I did a search and it seems like a common problem. No one can help of course because it's out of warranty. So I have to unplug it every other day and tap the buttons and blow air into it because it gets "stuck," even though I've only touched the buttons a couple times in the year I've owned this monitor.Other than that the monitor is great for its price point. product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Great Monitor, But Curious Discrepancy
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on March 30, 2020
text: For the price, these are fantastic monitors.  As with most monitors, set up and use is simple, and the provided HDMI cable means nothing extra to purchase.  I would probably not use this for serious, detailed photo editing but for general daily computer use it's excellent, but with one curious discrepancy (flaw?).  I got used to using two monitors at my office, so I bought two of these to use side by side.  They look identical, and if they were not side by side I would never have noticed, but one stands about 1/4 inch taller than the other.  It must be the stand or where the stand is attached, as the difference is the same on the top and bottom of the monitor itself, but it appears that the stand is fixed and not height-adjustable.  Every once in a while it bothers me (but that's my issue), but it does not detract from the monitor's performance.

text: I purchased this monitor, as I will be working from home for an extended period during the pandemic.  PROs:Slim frame, not heavy, easy setup, reasonably priced, blue light reduction option, cables were included (HDMI, VGA, and a simple power cord) - not having special cards is a plus if you happen to misplace the ones provided.CONs:The back of the monitor is not equipped to have a plate for mounting. (After purchasing, I realized getting it off the desk would allow more workspace.) So, I had to buy an adapter for the desk mount.The monitor does not have speakers - which may be a deal breaker for some.Ultimately, I would likely repurchase, if needed.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Light leaks galore and slow when turning on
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on October 30, 2020
text: I have two of these monitors and I like them well enough.They are slow to turn on, and show a lot of green and white static and flicker for a few seconds initially. When the Acer logo pops up the light leaks are obvious, but once I get to my home screen and get to work (engineering software/matlab and typing) it isn't noticeable. (Using a brand new Mac mini for what it's worth.)Overall, good for my purpose at this price. The only annoying thing was buying VESA adaptors in order to hang them above my desk. These are lightweight enough that there is no reason they shouldn't have the VESA plate built in already.

text: Works great! The stand isn't adjustable and it doesn't come with an hdmi, but hey - this monitor is great, especially considering the price. You aren't gonna beat anything like this.The thing I'm sad about was that I wasn't able to grab a 24" since it was sold out so I got the 21.5", but that's no fault of the manufacturer, mostly my own bad timing.I didn't need to manually set the frame rate to 75hz or turn on freesync, it did it on its own, which was surprising and very nice. It's an ips, so it's got great viewing angles. I've only had this screen for a month and have had absolutely zero problems so far!EDIT: So one problem, but it doesn‚Äôt change my star rating. Setting the monitor into overdrive (which I don‚Äôt even know what that does) creates like a blue shadow effect behind figures and shapes a half second behind. It‚Äôs odd. But I turned it to normal, and zero problems!

title: Holly and Aylei please stop reading my reviews

text: Monitor is fantastic. Fits in my luggage so I can travel with it everywhere. Also really good for Super Smash Brothers Ultimate. True story, just today I played my first game of Smash in two months. My first game was part of an online tournament and I ended up winning the tournament. Was really proud of myself as not only had my Piranha Plant skills not decreased over the past two months, they had actually improved! I texted my friend back home to brag about how exceptional I am and a few games later learned that these tournaments are filled with bots. Holly and Aylei if you're still reading, what are you doing... As I said in my Helen Keller review, A Long Walk To Freedom or The Power of Now is a way better use of time. I'd recommend reading those books instead of my reviews.This monitor is fantastic. It's durable, a great size for traveling, and has good resolution. I use it for gaming and working and constantly have huge spreadsheets on it.

title: ou get what you pay for, but it should at least work!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on July 16, 2020
text: While this monitor does deliver vibrant colors for a budget price, there are some serious defects. It has lousy blacks, especially from an angle. If you're not directly in front of the monitor looking slightly down at it, you'll be very disappointed if you have a dark or black-based screen saver. The blues are a little hot but can be corrected with color and gamma balance, but it takes a slow and steady hand, even you're used to working with Acer's clunky interface.I've used several other Acer monitors over the years and I will use them again, but not this model. It's the worst LED monitor I've ever purchased.I would recommend that you stay clear of this monitor and continue shopping.

The only downside: I was moving my macbook pro around this morning and lightly grazed the monitor. This caused a 4 inch scratch on the monitor. I hoped it was just dirt, but after scrubbing and running my nail over the area, it's clear that the screen is now scratched and I'm going to have to live with it. It's not too much of a problem, but know that the screen material is very delicate and easy to scratch. If you want something a little more durable, maybe go up a price point.

text: You've seen the other reviews. This is an excellent monitor for what it is. I've been using it for 4 months now. I use it primarily for gaming and schoolwork, and it serves the purpose fine. THIS IS A 75HZ MONITOR. It will bottleneck your pc on most games. But if you are looking for a great side monitor, or your rig just can't handle more than 60 fps, this is a great option. If you are looking for a monitor for work, just buy 3 of these and BOOM you've got yourself a great productivity monitor setup for less than $300. I can't say enough good things about this monitor. If $100 is all you have for a monitor, you can't go wrong with this one.

text: Wow. All I had to do was unbox it, plug in the cable & power cord, hit the power button, and I had a beautiful, clear, crisp display. No drivers to download/install, no set up, etc. Took 2 seconds to attach to desktop stand. Literally plug & play. Very slim & light weight, but doesn't have a flimsy or cheap look or feel at all. Works well w/my Acer laptop & daughter's Lenovo laptop, as well as her Dell work laptop w/docking station.  Tilts & adjusts easily & smoothly w/out slipping or sticking. Really pleased with it, probably ordering another for daughter to use while working from home. Doesn't have mic, camera or speakers, but if you're using w/laptop that has them, just do a dual display or multi-screen mode and you should be fine using the laptop for video calls.

text: As most of us in the tech industry are now working from home I needed another monitor to extend from my laptop. I then hit Fn F8 to select extend screen and I was up and running.The only issue I ran into was my laptop speaker stopped working after a few minutes. text: I'm not a gamer, i don't do high graphic stuff on my computer, so i can't comment on if it's good for gaming or not. i'm coming from a laptop computer, went back to a desktop ('cause i wanted the works and my laptop was slower than molasses and yeah LOL). I watch literally ALL my tv on my computer - that's why i wanted this monitor. It really is as slim as you see in the pictures it is wider towards the bottom center than the edges (which are all slim). It's adjustable and beyond decent imaging. The connections to the base is really strong (it's not clip on plastic, there's a metal locking system w/screw at the bottom for a solid connection). The size fits my heritage desk perfectly. I am 100% pleased with this purchase and would buy it all over again in a heartbeat. Add: contrary to other reviews; this monitor DOES tilt.

title: Reasonable For The Price
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 11, 2019
text: Mine has one dead pixel within a few centimeters of the top-left corner, but the rest of the display looks pristine after an hour of use. Acer guarantees fewer than six dead pixels on this size of display, and it's not in the way, so I'm not too fussed, even though this is the first display I've ever bought that had any. (This is also the cheapest display I've ever bought.) There's a bit of bleed-through at the bottom-right, where the controls are, and pressing the bezel near the controls flexes the screen enough to affect it. It might be possible to damage the display by grabbing the frame there while you're adjusting the controls, which would be my natural inclination. After adjusting the contrast and brightness, it looks pretty good. I could definitely watch movies and do normal tasks on it.

My only issues I have with this monitor is that I have a pair of them hooked up to my docking station for my work laptop and either the laptop or the work station seems to be forcing the incorrect aspect ratio which either makes me cut the screen size to scale it properly or lose text and images. The other issue was that the stands that come with the monitors are not very adjustable with the two of mine for some reason being at different heights even though they have the same stands and angle which is irritating but nothing major.

title: Very good for the price
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2019
text: For this price, this monitor is fantastic. The bezels are really nice and thin, and the viewing angles and color of the panel are also good thanks to it being IPS.It being 75hz is a little strange, because it looks noticeably smoother than 60hz, but not nearly as smooth and 120, landing it right in this weird middle-ground that could be jarring for some users. Also, VGA on this monitor feels very strange to me, seeing as we're pushing 1080p 75hz, a DisplayPort would feel much more at home on this monitor.But for this price, it's absolutely the best out there. Color and viewing angles are great, brightness is great, and it looks pretty sleek with it's thin bezels. Overall nice purchase.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Poor RGB color blending
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2022
text: I ordered 2 and they both have the same problem, regardless of HDMI or VGA input, though it is much more noticeable on HDMI.  Blended colors (Cyan, Orange, Magenta) have vertical "lines" in them where it looks like one column of pixels is more saturated than the next column and it alternates back and forth resulting in a very annoying effect.  The color accuracy is also very poor on the monitors.  I had to adjust the colors in the menu pretty heavily to get good results.  I've tried both monitors on 2 computers with the same results. I've tried different HDMI cables, I've tried a laptop dock, directly into a laptop, a USB to HDMI adapter... all the same result. I've concluded it is an issue with the monitor. I wish I could return them but threw the boxes away.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: This would be a great monitor if it wouldn't die
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on May 21, 2021
text: Don't let the high needs buyers put you off with their very high requirements. If you're a business user and moderate gamer like me you'll be very happy with this purchase. If you're doing precise color matching, need higher pixel densities or very high end gaming you might want to read the reviews that weren't so happy with this monitor to see what you need instead. I'm very happy with this monitor.After 18 months this monitor died while I was using it. I checked out the power supply and it was working fine. But the monitor would no longer turn on. Of course it was out of  warranty and I had a decision. Do I order another one? I have monitors that I bought in 2003 still in service and working fine. I've NEVER had a monitor failure of any kind on a monitor less than 10 years old. What are the chances that I have another very early death? Isn't Acer a good company?Well, apparently the odds of another failure are 100%. I received my new Acer SB220Q on July 28. This morning, September 8, it died during use, exactly as my first monitor did. There are definitely some substandard components inside this model. Now I have a 13 year old monitor plugged in as a temporary substitute.An LCD monitor should have a guaranteed 10 year lifespan, not less than 2 years. Even a monitor that lasts only 3 years would be a travesty. But I have purchased two Acer SB220Q monitors now. One died in 18 months and the newest only lasted a little more than one month.This is unacceptable. I hope Amazon doesn't ream me on the warranty process.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi

text: I bought two of these for use in dual monitor setup with an Aspire V17 Nitro and I'm rather impressed with the quality of these monitors. First of all they look far more premium than the price would suggest and also in part to their size, the displays look very sharp. I have the two displays plugged into my machine via HDMI although I did have to use a Thunderbolt 3 to HDMI converter to properly run this setup(this will differ by computer). So far this has not presented any issues with quality so I'm pleased with the results of running these in dual configuration. I didn't do a whole lot of gaming on these(as they are primarily for a workstation) but I would suspect most games will look fine on these screens so long as you're not overly concerned about refresh rate. Overall I think is monitor is a great buy.

text: I just bought this for my husband as an early Christmas present since his died this morning. He's heavy into gaming and his old monitor was terrible. I've been looking at this one for a while so I decided to make the jump. I'm so glad I did! The colors on this monitor are so vivid on the default that we had to turn down the brightness a tad. title: Simple install, Great color, has a weird ripple on white screen.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2019
text: I use this as my garage computer screen. Simple and easy setup. Packaging was great and protected it thoroughly.  Enough cord to allow for distance and tucking of wires. My only complaint is that on a white screen, such as this web browser(google), there is a black ripple effect that is prominent. Sometimes it pulses, sometimes its a ripple. Imagine opening up a blank notepad on the windows app, and having a black/grey shadow in the background. It does not go away. I've watched a movie and use it for multiple social media browsing and a video game. It works great, it really shows you different colors and definition. I'm annoyed by the background black/grey ripples but am very pleased with performance and color otherwise. I would buy it again and would recommend to friends.

title: Great quality screen for the money
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2018
text: This is a basic, no frills, monitor with a beautiful picture & well deserved reputation for lasting a long time.  No built in speaker, get a different model if that is what you want.  Not for the novice, as the only usable instruction is "turn off computer before installing".  There are 5 buttons on the bottom edge of the monitor, but pictograms are useless.  But, don't worry; after you make all connections & power up the computer & monitor, the monitor checks connections & automatically picks the correct settings for you.  If you have an HDMI connection on your computer (preferably on the back panel), use that instead of the VGA cable to get the best quality picture.  (You must supply the cable.)

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: BEWARE of the "Input Not Supported" Problem
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2022
text: When I installed the monitor, I immediately ran into the "input not supported" problem.I had been unaware of the issue, but when I googled, I found that it's well-known and that Acer monitors are specifically and particularly subject to it.The impact of the problem is that when the Windows sign-in screen comes up, it looks great and everything from that point on is fine; but you cannot see or interact with anything prior to that point (e.g.,  you cannot see the bios screens if you try to activate bios while booting the system, and you can't see or interact with the safemode startup screens).There are multiple sites that describe corrective steps, e.g., techisours.com/input-not-supported/ - but none of the sites and none of the steps worked for me.I plan to return the monitor to Amazon.  Given how widespread the problem is, I'm surprised that it doesn't show up in the Amazon reviews, nor given how long it's been going on (5yr+) that Acer doesn't fix it.You may be lucky:  Apparently most users don't suffer the failure.  But if your luck is like mine, I'd suggest buying something else.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi

text: For $90, this is a great monitor for gaming.  It's a 1080p, 75Hz IPS display with FreeSync.  At this price-point, this is a steal.  Picture quality is excellent and colors are vibrant. The size is a little smaller than I was expecting, but it's still good.  All in all, you're getting a lot for your money with this monitor and I highly recommend this for all the ballers on budgets out there who are looking for good quality at an affordable price.

text: I needed an extra monitor in my home office and didn't want to spend too much. for the price this is an amazing monitor. It is very light and thin. There is hardly a frame bezel, and if you were to place two side by side it will be pretty seamless. Of course with the price there are certain trade-offs, the stand doesn't move vertically so you cannot adjust the height. It was the perfect height for me so didn't matter much. You can tilt and rotate the monitor. It doesn't come with VESA mounting holes so if you want to attach it to an arm that will not work. I think it is a great value for the price but make sure to know the limitation for your specific needs.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Fairly blurry monitor -- wife gets motion sick
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2020
text: Running a GeForce 1080 Ti and a Ryzen 7 3800X, this monitor shows pretty strong signs of motion blur. Panning left/right when there's a dark object against a light sky, shows multiple ghosts of the object, just like you'll see with high-persistence monitors. Turning on "overdrive" gives the objects white edge outlines, but doesn't really reduce the effect. This is not super surprising given that it's an IPS panel, but I had hoped with 75 Hz and overdrive (and the VRR from free-sync) it wouldn't be so noticeable. It's certainly not "4 ms gray-to-gray" in any meaningful way.Unfortunately, my wife gets motion sickness from this persistence when playing Overwatch, so I wouldn't call this a "gaming monitor" in the same class as real G-sync monitors.

This way I was not putting pressure on the monitor It worked. For the money it is a great monitor.

title: An excellent monitor at a very good price
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on October 30, 2019
text: Extremely easy to assemble, just three pieces and they slip together easily, they'll only fit one way. It does tilt, half an inch forward and three inches back. Screen does not glare. Colors and brightness are good. Color looks great to me, but a professional photographer would probably be more picky re color accuracy than I am. Very light weight. Has two ports: VGA and HDMI, and they are easy to access, right on the back of the screen, not concealed. I use the HDMI exclusively since my video card happens to have an HDMI output. I would buy it again, and will if/when other computers around the house need new monitors.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Hit or miss with quality
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 28, 2020
text: I originally purchased one of these monitors when I needed to work from home and things worked great so I decided to buy an identical one. I didn't get a chance to set it up for a few weeks as I was waiting for monitor arms but as soon as I set it up I recognized that the screen would flicker like the contrast would get turned all the way up until I touched the monitor and it returned to normal. I troubleshot with several hdmi cables, difference computers and the problem remained. It was annoying but I figured it was cheap enough to just deal with it, the final straw was when I recognized screen burn and sent it in to Acer for repair (support was super nice)  After paying for shipping and waiting two weeks they sent it back and said they couldn't find anything wrong with it. I plugged it in and immediately the issue was apparent and has been deteriorating every day.I'm a bit disappointed because I really liked the first monitor I bought but the lack of support for the second faulty one is going to prevent me from purchasing Acer brand in the future.Picture attached is screen burn after 10 minutes of a YouTube video.

title: Best monitor for Budget Gaming PC

title: I don't want to support this company
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on September 18, 2020
text: I bought this monitor for 3 main reasons. It was 1080p, 75hz, and 21.5 inches. The monitor was 21.5 inches, yes, but I have never seen a more strange border around a screen. The border was about a 1/2 inch thick, and about an 1/8 inch on the bottom. Less of a functionality thing, more just poor aesthetic. However, this monitor was not 75hz, and that was a big problem for me. I went to display settings, the highest refresh rate setting was 60hz. I tried overclocking, and it topped out around 70hz. This was the second time this has happened to me. The first time I let it slide because I needed a new monitor, but this time I was very frustrated. I saw everywhere, "1920x1080, 75hz". And if that means 1080p runs at 60, and other resolutions can run at 75, then don't put those 2 numbers anywhere close to each other. And, additionally, the monitor itself was just bad. The monitor flickered, when I moved my mouse it would have a weird white tint, and when I was just scrolling through a webpage all the text would get a weird shadow while scrolling. The only reason I gave this 2 stars was because it was 1080p like advertised.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi

If you're planning on spending any less than $200 on a monitor, this is the one to get.

title: Commonly has dead pixels

text: Overall, this is a great product for the average gamer, video editor, or photo editor.However, there is a couple of issue with it. The biggest being dead pixels. I've purchased two of these monitors for my dual monitor setup. And unfortunately, both of them have at least one dead pixel. On one monitor, it's near the center. And the other being on the top left.Past the dead pixels, if you use this for gaming and might use the built-in crosshair. Then the crosshair built into the monitor can unfortunately not be scaled and is absolutely massive.Besides that, it's overall a pretty decent cheap monitor. You may have to adjust the brightness and contrast a bit. But that's an easy enough fix. A quick tip, however. You CAN tilt this monitor up and down. It's just a bit tricky the first time doing it.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Pixelated colors, terrible contrast
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2021
text: This is the worst monitor I've purchased in the last 15 years. Even on HDMI it looks worse than a decades old VGA monitor. I bought it to use as a second monitor, mostly for text and chat apps and even for that purpose it's unbearable.Colors look incredibly pixelated, giving everything a "screen door" effect. You can notice it most prominently with light blue. What shows up as a solid light blue rectangle on my primary monitor shows up as essentially a series of vertical blue lines on this piece of junk.Secondly, the contract is absolutely horrible. It always has a washed-out look. Adjusting the contrast didn't resolve the pixelated color issue. There's a permanent hazy tinge to the screen that makes your eyes hurt.Anyone who reviews this monitor positively simply hasn't used another monitor made this century. Of the thousands of amazon products I've bought in my short life, this is a serious contender for the worst one ever.

location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on December 22, 2020
text: Everything came packed perfectly, and installation was a breeze. After hooking everything up I noticed that I was unable to modify sound in any way. Of course the PC recognized there was a monitor and the drivers had no issues playing sound to the monitor. But the monitor was unable to play sound. The settings for sound were just completely grayed out meaning i could not access them. I tried several cables so I know it's not the cables. I plugged in a USB headset and played sound no problem so its not the PC. I'm pretty upset that I had thought i'd gotten such a good deal grabbing this on sale but nope, had to sacrifice audio. Luckily this monitor is for my wife who is hearing impaired so it gives her an excuse to use my headset to listen to any audio. It's a great monitor so I'm sure I just had some bad luck, I'd still recommend this as a decent monitor.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Fell in Love with Dual Monitors and Had it Snatched Away From Me
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2021
text: I bought this monitor to use alongside my laptop for a coding class so I could follow along on Zoom and code simultaneously. This monitor made me immensely happy, increasing my productivity and focus in the class and other endeavors.However, after about a month of having it, there were suddenly dead pixels in a corner of the screen, completely obscuring the right corner from being readable. Annoying, but I didn't have another $100 to spend, so I could deal with it. When I noticed these dead pixels, there was also a strange screen flickering, but it went away after a bit, so I ignored it. However, this was an omen because two weeks later the screen flickering became so constant that the screen was basically unreadable. I updated drivers, replaced HDMI cables, attempted to reduce electrical noise near the monitor... Some things worked, but nothing completely solved it.Which brings me to present day, where the second screen won't even bother to show my desktop anymore. Now it just flashes the Acer startup logo over and over again. I don't know why this screen decided to fail on me, but since it started failing outside of the return window I guess I'm just SOL. I'll look elsewhere for a monitor when I have the funds.

title: Returned 2 Of These

text: I returned 2 of them.  I couldn't handle the definition of the pixels.  A section which was supposed to be a solid blue or orange it was liked zebra stripped up and down.  Almost like the aliasing filtering was messed up.  I tried adjusting many features (sharpness, contrast, etc) and could not get it correct.  The pictures don't do it justice for how bad it was for me, it was hard to get a picture of it, but it was unacceptable to me.  You can kinda see it in the amazon smile and some in the color squares image.  I bought two of these (ASUS VP229Q 21.5‚Äù Monitor, 1080P Full HD, 75Hz, IPS, FreeSync/Adaptive-Sync, Eye Care, HDMI DisplayPort VGA, Frameless, VESA Wall Mountable BLACK).  They are much better for me.  The only problem with them I have is that when I type the table shakes a little and the monitor wiggles.  I think the mount isn't as solid/rigid, but I'm going to figure out how to work on it.

title: Nice monitor, NOISY on RF. Works great with Raspberry.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2018
text: This is a great monitor. Smooth, thin, good color. But its NOISY with RF. I bought this to use with my Raspberry Pi, because it has an HDMI input. The input works fine and the raspberry has no issues with it. My only problem is, I got this to use next to my ham radio, and on 7mhz band it makes a little static on the band, not too bad. On 14mhz it makes a LOT of static. Almost to the point that I have to turn it off. On the 3.9mhz section it has several "birdies" that it produces - loud eeeeeeeeeee tones that switch off when the screen is off. The power cord is shielded so it has to be somehting inside the screen I cant shield. So, good monitor but if it is near your radio, you will have to turn it off.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Stopped working after one month
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on September 6, 2020
text: For the price, this monitor is great while it works. However, according to other reviews and now my own, this monitor doesn't last long. I noticed occasional black screens when I first started using it and worried that might be a precursor to something worse. It was.After only 4 weeks of using this monitor, the screen is black and will not display anything (from the pc, from the monitor itself, nothing). When starting my pc, the monitor acknowledges the input and attempts to display something but fails every time. Occasional spurts of color try and come through but last only half a second. I attempted every fix you could imagine short of opening up the monitor. Different cables. Different computer. Checked my hardware inside my pc. Nothing worked.Just started the return process today before it was too late. Save yourself the hassle and invest in something sturdier even if the price of this monitor makes it hard to turn down.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Decent monitor for the price, but with one worrying issue (UPDATE 4/3/2020)
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 13, 2019
text: This monitor worked great for about 2 or 3 weeks, but then all of a sudden my colors became really pixelated. Greenish pixels appeared all over the screen, which made it look terrible, especially when trying to watch videos. Checked all the connections and settings, couldn't find any issues. Googled around, and couldn't find anything on the internet either. Then about an hour after it started, it stopped. Only thing I did was *lightly* slap the back of the monitor (mostly from frustration) and the issue disappeared. My wild guess is that it was caused by a poor internal connection. I'm worried that the issue will come back, but it's been another week and no issues so far. I'll update this review if anything changes. Of note is that the return window is now closed - hopefully Acer will honor the warranty if it happens again.Also, there's no VESA mounting holes on the back, which is just an unacceptable oversight IMO. It would be super cheap and easy to add them into the manufacturing process, and without them, I'm forced to blow 20 bucks on an adapter to be able to use a mount. For a $90 monitor without a height-adjustable stand, it's really kind of a rip-off to not have them. Overall, I give this product a 3.5/5 currently, rounded up to a 4.UPDATE: The same green pixelated issue came back last week. Tried everything, can't get it to go away. Monitor is essentially worthless now. I'm looking into the product warranty. STAY AWAY from this product, and spend a little more to get a reliable brand.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Couldn't get it to display while in BIOS
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on October 12, 2019
text: Bought this monitor for my new PC build.  Unfortunately I could not get it to display while in BIOS.  The first time I set up my computer I had to drag it to a TV and connect it so I could get BIOS displayed and begin loading Windows 10.  Once Windows 10 was loaded I updated my video card drivers and updated everything.. tried to go into BIOS, it did not display.  The screen says "input not supported" it does not come on until after my computer gets to the windows login screen.  I called Acer support.  They suggested all the things I already tried (different cables, update BIOS)  nothing worked.  Due to this issue I am returning this monitor.  I'm A+ certified and a professional in I.T. ..  I'm stumped by the issue and so was Acer.  I'm sure there is some sort of display settings mismatch while in BIOS but to be completely honest after troubleshooting this much and not having any further direction from tech support I think it's not worth it..  returning it and getting a different model from a different company.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: screen burns after less than a year, support is terrible
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2021
text: This seemed to be a decent monitor for a low price, as I needed one right away. The colors were always a little muddled, but since I was using it as a secondary, it wasn't bothersome. However, I have owned it for less than a year and anything left open for even a short time (less than an hour) is burning afterimages onto the screen, even my desktop image is burning. Each time this occurs, it's taking longer and longer for the images to fade, in a few places it doesn't look like it will ever fade away. The screen overall is becoming rapidly grainy, I've never seen such a deterioration on a monitor before.Edit: After contacting their customer service and discussing their limited 3 year warranty (which does state repair/replace/refund options), they refuse to refund me purchase price, insisting instead that I send the monitor off to them at cost to myself for repairs. I do not trust that this would give me more than another 7-8 months before another failure. Will not be making a purchase from this company again.

title: A year into WFH with this monitor and it struggles
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2021
text: I bought this back in early March 2020 thinking I'd be working from home for a few weeks (hah!). Since then, this monitor has been my main screen that I plug my laptop into. The size, display, color, etc are fine but something seems to be wrong with it electrically. It started turning off on me randomly several months ago and now does it a few times a day. I have to unplug and plug it back in multiple times to get the display to come back on. So unfortunately, a year into WFH, I'll be buying a new, more reliable monitor. I'd say this monitor works great for temporary use but is not a good option if you'll be working on it every day!

title: Was sent a faulty, used monitor. Buyer beware.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on March 16, 2020
text: This monitor would be really great, but I believe that I was sent a faulty refurbished version. Right out of the box, the screen was flickery and terrible, but I adjusted the refresh rate and it looked great ‚Äî one one side. The other side was still dark and horrible on the eyes. I contacted Acer customer support and when I gave them the serial number, they asked me to confirm that the purchase date. According to them, this monitor was purchased 9/19/19. I purchased it 3/12/20, brand new. Fishy? Definitely. This monitor is clearly a refurb, and upon further inspection, I noticed that the screws had sharpie marks on them as if they were being checked by an refurb inspection team. There was no disclosure that this item was used. I'm super annoyed and distrustful of this seller.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Abruptly stopped working after less than 2 months of sporadic use
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2020
text: This monitor was great while it worked, but then I started my computer one day, the monitored flickered as if releasing a few dying breaths, and then left me with nothing other than a blank screen. It powers on and my computer still recognizes it as an external display, but other than a split-second flicker here and there, it's total blankness.Now, after barely more than a month with a total usage time of probably 20-30 hours, I've had to contact support and will have to pack and ship the monitor and wait up to a month for them to fix it. For the amount of time and effort required for the repair, you think they'd just send me a new one, but hey, I'm not the one making the decisions. All I know is that I'm probably just going to spend another ~$80 on a monitor from another company given the alternative of facing a month of frustration and decreased productivity by being forced to rely on my 13" inch laptop screen. So, with that all being said, it has proven to be a regrettable purchase.

title: Barely made it 2 months

text: Bought this product at the beginning of March, made it to mid May. I was on my computer one night browsing the web, all of a sudden my screen went black. Then I started to smell burning plastic. At first I thought my PC was overheating as I have been having issues with the cooling fans. But eventually I narrowed it down to the screen. I do use my computer a lot. I have this hooked up to my laptop docking station for work which I use during the day, and it‚Äôs also connected to my personal computer for gaming and other personal uses. I think it‚Äôs safe to say that it couldn‚Äôt handle that amount of usage. Now I have to use my tiny laptop  screen for work and have no display for my PC until my replacement comes in. So if you are like me and constantly using it, might be more worth your time to shell out the extra cash for a better quality monitor. Luckily it broke in time for me to return for a refund. If you are using occasionally might last you a little longer than 2 months but to be safe I‚Äôd stay away.

text: Package came with a sticker saying thanks for a second home. I thought no way I was under the impression it was new as it didn't state on the page it was refurbished. I opened the package, which was beat the crap out of. and opening it up to find NO PACKING BUBBLE WRAP or anything to help support it from damage. ALSO NO cord that would allow me to connect to a computer. ONLY the power cable came with the package. Like everything was just thrown in there with no consideration. THE MONITER itself had multiple small scratches that wouldn't go away and SMEAR marks all over the screen. How can acer be okay with putting together this kind of product and almost like it's just trying to get their moneys worth. As if who cares let's see if they keep it. I'd Highly recommend NOT to purchase this product unless stated as REFURBISHED on their page as it's NOT new.

I'm not going to ruin my eyesight over a monitor.Very disappointed.  I've tried to live with it but I'm no longer willing to deal with it.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Screen blacks out 10-50 times per day
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on December 15, 2020
text: Reduced rating to one star. Absolutely no support provided from Amazon or the manufacturer. I will have to pay out of pocket FROM SOMEWHERE ELSE to get a monitor that stays on longer than ten minutes. What a total POS this is. Complete waste of money.I purchased two of these monitors so I could work from home. One of them works well, but the other blacks out often. Sometimes the screen comes back on with no issue. Sometimes it comes back, but purple or green. Sometimes it comes back, and the right side of the screen is on the left and vice versa. And sometimes it doesn't come back at all, and I have to unplug it from the computer and plug it back in. This didn't start happening until after the return deadline had passed. I've only had these for five months or so, so I am highly disappointed in this product. I will not be purchasing this brand again.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Loses connection sporadically
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on September 4, 2019
text: This was a great price, I loved that it was thin and lightweight, and I was happy to see it had great reviews. But sadly I was one of the few who had issues with it randomly shutting down or disconnecting. If you read the 1-star reviews, you'll see this pattern. It would work for awhile, then suddenly disconnect completely. Other times I couldn't get it to come up at all. I tried two different HDMI cables as well as a VGA cable, I tried it with two different laptops, my Lenovo from work and my personal Dell. But same thing over and over. I returned the first one to Amazon thinking it was defective. Tried the replacement one with all 3 cables and both laptops again, and same thing. Had my tech-saavy spouse try both monitors to make sure I wasn't missing anything. But alas, we couldn't identify the issue. Not sure why this seems to happen for some people and not for everyone. Will have to try something else. Bummer. The times it did work, it had a decent image and was the perfect size and weight.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Issues with Mac - Do Not Recommend
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on September 10, 2019
text: I bought two of these monitors and haven't even opened the second one yet because I've been so frustrated with the first one. It has a lot of trouble connecting with my thunderbolt 2 port (only this monitor has issues, I use this port on many other displays with no issues). Also makes give you the feature to split the screen between windows and adjust where the split is but if you split the screen on this monitor, you can't adjust the split and both screens are usually unusable. You have to gather the windows are your laptop display to be able to adjust then constantly move it to the other display until you get the right setup (as soon as you change applications, you have to start over again). Really inconvenient. Lastly, the brightness hardly adjusts down. At the lowest setting, it's still much brighter than other monitors which makes it hard to use if you work at night with the lights out.Maybe for really casual use, it would be okay but if you're serious about work, then don't buy a monitor that limits the functionality of your machine.

product_name: Acer 21.5 Inch Full HD (1920 x 1080) IPS Ultra-Thin Zero Frame Computer Monitor (HDMI & VGA Port), SB220Q bi
title: Flat colors, headache inducing, cheaply built.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 1, 2019
text: I got this monitor for regular use and it strains my eyes so bad, its just blurry enough. The black colors are basically a light grey and the screen is a matte plastic. Like the saturation/contrast are terrible and upping the contrast does nothing but make the screen brighter, not change the contrast. I do work involving precise colors, and play video games and everything just looks terrible on this screen. It's also too tall. WAY too tall. The power cord is flimsy, the base looks so cheap, and its just terrible. I've bought other monitors at this price point and they've done better than this. Do yourself a favor and get a Sceptre brand monitor for a similar price point or wait and spend a bit more. This monitor is AWFUL. "Best monitor I've used!" Hello? I guess I made the mistake of trusting the reviews not realizing people have never actually used a high quality monitor before. It also has TERRIBLE ghosting, and it does not even hit 60 hertz. Take it from someone who actually knows what good picture quality looks like: DO NOT BUY THIS IF YOU CARE!!!

text: I found that the snap in connection of the base to the monitor is not secure. Handling or moving the moniotor while only holding by the base is dangerous and as in my case caused the monitor to come apart from the base and fall to the floor and breaking the screen. When you put the base together to the monitor it sounds and feels like it has connected well (snap in) but will not stay together well if any other direction of force than down is applied. Even after i got a replacement and knew about this weakness it still was dicey moving the monitor. Be careful. Other than that the picture quality is good and it works well.

title: Defective, Ghosted/Ignored by Acer Support
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on February 16, 2021
text: After 2 months of general use, a vertical bar of dead pixels encompassed my entire screen.After speaking with Acer support for over 30 minutes, I was told I had to ship in the monitor for repair if it was deemed faulty--and that I had to cover shipping costs.Shipping costs would easily cost half the price of this monitor--and I needed a replacement ASAP.I was told I could not go for an in-person repair due to COVID, which I understand, but shipping costs for a faulty product should be waived.To make matters worse, Acer support never got back to me after the initial phone call. I am sitting here weeks later with a broken monitor, and instead bought a decades-old monitor from a friend for $20, which has proven to be a better value.

text: Second Acer monitor I have purchased. Has a line down the middle of the screen. First monitor had the same issue, but I figured there was no way that they could both have the same problems.. I contacted Acer support who told me to ship them the monitor as it was under warranty. However that shipping was at my cost, which was nearly half the price of the monitor itself. Rather than go through the hassle, I am just keeping it and will not buy another Acer product again.Yes, I have tried multiple cables. Yes, I have tried multiple computers. It's a monitor issue.

I use it to connect it to my macbookpro as a bigger monitor and the letters in the mac document look great but when I move it to the monitor, they are blurry and gives me eye strain. So I do not recommend this monitor if you want it for work/writing.

title: Do not buy
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on May 26, 2019
text: This product is an unadulterated failure. In the first month the power supply failed and the monitor would not turn on, no big deal I was fortunate enough to have a spare that fit the bill. Called customer service to have a replacement sent and the rep on the other end could not have cared less about my problems and just said they would be in touch via email, still waiting on that email btw. The final straw came when the monitor decided to stop working entirely last week, power cycled the monitor, restarted computer, tried detecting the monitor manually and changed HDMI cables to no avail. Plan to throw this in the trash where it belongs and never buying another Acer product again. My only hope is that my misfortune is warning enough to another honest buyer looking for a monitor at a reasonable price. Buy any other product but this one and you will be one step ahead of me.
